dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grady--45-year-old novelist, professor, and insomniac--is in the midst of reading a story to the dozen college  STUDENTS who make up his Advanced Writing Workshop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...listening to her father's boots scrape like  chalk on the ancient steps of the church, then  grow faint, then disappear altogether.' As he finishes, GRADY ponders a PAIR of MAINTENANCE MEN,  perched on ladders in the quad below, stringing a LARGE  BANNER between two bare trees. The BANNER reads:

dialogues.speaker: WELCOME TO WORDFEST
dialogues.text: GRADY turns, peers at his students. They look as if  they've been on a field trip to the DMV. GRADY (cont'd)  (a wave of the pages)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So. .Anyone? A GIRL with jet-black hair turns to a PALE YOUNG MAN  sitting at a desk in the back of the classroom. He is JAM LEER, 19. Like GRADY a moment before, he is staring out t window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me get this straight. The girl with the  big lips is depressed because, each night, when  her father goes off to work at the bakery, her  mother sneaks some mysterious lover into the  house. Not only does this girl have to listen  to her mother working this guy in the next  room, she has to wash the sheets each morning  before Daddy gets home. After a few weeks of  this, she starts to go a little nutty/ so Daddy  takes her to confession--only, once she gets in  the box, she gets a whiff of the priest and  realizes he's the mother's secret lover. Is  that it? James Leer says nothing, huddling lower in the PATTY  OVERCOAT he wears.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean, Jesus. What is it with you Catholics?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right. Let's try to keep it constructive,  shall we? Howard, what about you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hated it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's not exactly what I meant by  constructive, Howard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think James should try to be more  constructive. This is my second semester with  him. His stories are brutal, man. They make me  want to kill myself. GRADY glances at James, but his face remains impassive.  Then--with a visible sense of relief--GRADY notices the  raised hand of the achingly beautiful HANNAH GREEN.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, Hannah?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think maybe we're missing the point. It  seems to me James' strength as a writer is that  he doesn't take us by the hand. He treats us  like adults. He respects us enough to forget  us. That takes . . . courage . GRADY nods, smiles subtly. Appreciative.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well put, Hannah. And a good note to end on, I  think.  (as the students rise)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't forget about WordFest this weekend. And  remember: those of you driving V.I.P.s to  tonight's cocktail party need to have them at  the Chancellor's house no later than 5:30. Hannah Green gathers her things, pauses by Grady.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks for that. He all right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think so. ..What about you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Me? Sure. Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just checking. GRADY watches her glide away in her CRACKED RED COWBOY  BOOTS, then starts to exit himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Turn out the light, please. GRADY pauses, studying the wan figure sitting at the back of the classroom, then--reluctantly-hits the switch on th wail, leaving James Leer alone in the DARK.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GRADY hurries down the steps, then spies SARA GASKSLL,  45, standing below. She is talking to a BOY with an armfu of SLICK PROGRAMS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calm but firm)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, Elliot, I said five hundred programs for  today. This means we have no programs for the  weekend. This means that tomorrow morning, at  9AM, several hundred people will walk into Thaw  Hall and have absolutely no idea where they are  going.  (shaking her head)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's all right, Elliot. I'll take care of it. GRADY watches Sara take the programs, turn, and spot him. There is the slightest of hesitations, then....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Professor Tripp.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chancellor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got the message you called.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got the message you called too. This hangs in the air, awkward somehow, then both nod and continue on, without so much as a backward glance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The RADIO BLASTS as GRADY pops the glove box, removes a  JOINT as big as his pinky, and wheels his DARK MAROON '66 GALAXIE RAGTOP away from campus, cruising under another

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GRADY cruises past the three rivers and modest  skyscrapers of downtown, sipping at the weed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GRADY rides the long, automated treadmill that runs half  the length of the terminal, until...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...TERRY CRABTREE--Grady's editor and friend-exits the  tunnel with a STUNNING YOUNG WOMAN in a skin-tight black  dress, bright red topcoat, and three-inch spike heels.   Grinning devilishly, Crabtree whispers something in the  woman's ear, then spots Grady.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tripp!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How are you, Crabtree?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brimming. Say hello to my new friend, Miss  Antonia. . .uh. . . .

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sloviak.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I took the liberty of inviting Antonia to  tonight's festivities. You don't mind, do you.  Trip? ?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a slight beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The more the merrier.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Terry was telling me about you on the plane.  It was ail so interesting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was explaining to Antonia how a book comes  to be published. What you do as a writer, what  I do as an editor...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I sweat blood for five years and he checks for  spelling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (indicating Crabtree)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's exactly what he said.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We know each other pretty well.  (to Grady)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So where's Emily?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Emily?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your wife.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh. We're picking her up. Downtown.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perfect. Well then, shall we? GRADY nods, but lingers briefly--studying the  architecture of Miss Sloviak's ankles as she CLICKS off i her spike heels, arm in arm with Crabtree.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GRADY and Crabtree watch suitcases tumble as Miss Sloviak sits across the way, inspecting her face in a compact.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you know how many times I've boarded an  airplane praying someone like her would sit  down beside me? Particularly while I'm on my  way to Pittsburgh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lay off Pittsburgh. It's one of the great  cities.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If it can produce a Miss Sloviak you'll get no  argument from me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's a transvestite.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're stoned.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's still a transvestite.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Isn't she? Crabtree ignores Grady's question, smiling placidly as he watches the carousel spin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So how's the book? GRADY stiffens. He had been expecting this, but not so  soon. He tries to act casual.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's fine. It's done. Basically. I'm just sort  of. ..tinkering with it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Great. I was hoping I could get a look at it  sometime this weekend. Think that might be  possible?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. I'm sort of at a critical. . .  juncture .

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought you were tinkering.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just mean. . .

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forget I asked. I don't want to pressure you,  Tripp. But... (pointedly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...I get pressure. Know what I mean? GRADY ponders this, troubled by it. Suddenly, Crabtree's  face brightens again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah. ..well now. What do you suppose that would  be? GRADY turns, watches an immense PONY HIDE CASE drop onto  the carousel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That would be a tuba.

dialogues.speaker: LATE AFTERNOON
dialogues.text: As the Galaxie emerges from a TUNNEL, GRADY watches the  great city of Pittsburgh reveal itself in the distance,  then glances in the rearview mirror.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That perfume you're wearing, Antonia. It  wouldn't happen to be Cristaile, would it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why yes. How did you know?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lucky guess.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You didn't actually purchase this car, did  you. Trip??

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was Jerry Nathan's. He owed me money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He owes God money. You know, he queered  himself for good with Esquire. GRADY takes a joint from the ashtray, snaps a Scripto  butane.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He said something about being between things.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, between a bookie and a pair of broken  legs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A YOUNG WOMAN with a crumpled PITTSBURGH STEEIERS  UMBRELLA exits the building and-seeing GRADY parked in  front of a fire hydrant--stops, a puzzled expression on h face. As she approaches, GRADY roils down the passenger  window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi, Tanya.  (to the others)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is Tanya. My wife's secretary. CRABTREE and MISS SLOVIAK smile and nod. Tanya smiles and nods back, her eyes passing uneasily over Grady's joint.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grady.. ..Emily's not here. GRADY just smiles, nods. TANYA (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is there anything I can do for you? GRADY watches a tiny stream of water trickle through  Tanya's sad umbrella.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're leaking, Tanya. Tanya nods--at a loss-then turns away into the rain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Trip? ?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She left me. Crabs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Left you...?  Who? Emily?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This morning. I found a note in the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But. ..why didn't you say something, Tripp? I  mean, what are we doing here? GRADY gazes at the glittering scene beyond his  windshield, turns on the ignition.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought maybe I made it all up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Through the windows, a rabble of writers, faculty and  select students can be SEEN, mingling under a haze of  cigarette smoke. GRADY brings the Galaxie to a lurching  halt across the street, parks in front of another fire  hydrant. As the trio steps out. MISS SLOVIAK notices a  GREENHOUSE, shimmering quietly in the chill night air.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's a nice greenhouse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's Mrs. Gaskell's. Her hobby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought you were Mrs. Gaskell's hobby,  Tripp.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Piss off, Crabs. I lost a wife today.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I'm sure you'll find another. You always  do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the front door swings open, Sara Gaskell appears,  riding a wave of jagged party CHATTER onto the porch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, hello, everyone. Terry, good to see you  again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chancellor. Don't you look ravishing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aren't you sweet to say so. I was beginning to  wonder if you were ever going to--oh! As Sara steps forward, her heel-catches and she pitches  forward ...into Grady's arms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Easy there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry. It's these goddamned shoes. I don't  know how anyone actually walks in these things.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Practice. Sara looks at Miss Sloviak, a faint glitter of scientific curiosity in her eye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't believe we've met...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Antonia. Antonia Sloviak-- Just then, a THICKLY-MUCSCLED DOG with very strange EYES  skitters around the corner, BARKING SAVAGELY in the gener direction of Grady.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Poe!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (mildly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This wouldn't be Walter's dog, would it? Poe continues to rage, his paws doing crazy eights on the hardwood floor, until he's spun himself completely around and is barking at the living room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who ' s he barking at now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's still barking at me. He's blind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Poe' Hush! Now stop this. Honestly. As Poe simmers to a deep growl, GRADY leans forward.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I need to talk to you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's funny. I need to talk to you, too.  (strategy in her tone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perhaps you could put some of these coats in  the upstairs guest room, Professor Tripp.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reading her)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't believe I know where the upstairs  guest room is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well then. I'd better show you. Terry--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll just make ourselves at home. (kneeling by Poe)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Won't we, Poe? Yes, yes....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GRADY enters a room swimming in BASEBAIL MEMORABILIA.  AUTOGRAPHED BASEBALLS abound, as well as PHOTOGRAPHS of  famous big-leaguers. In one somewhat-dated PHOTO a TRIM M IN HIS FORTIES (a younger Walter Gaskell) stands with  PITTSBURGH PIRATE BILL MAZEROSKI at an old-timers game. A Sara eases the door shut, GRADY nods to a 1951 YANKEE'S  PENNANT hanging over the mantle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: New?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nodding)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter just got it back from the framer today. Sara takes Grady's hand, drawing him away from the  pennant and down onto the coat-covered bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You go first.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right. This morning--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm pregnant. A flash of LAUGHTER flutters from the living  room below. GRADY starts to speak.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well. This is...surprising. Does Walter... ?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think Walter would find this a little more  than surprising. GRADY nods, getting her drift, then roils onto his back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Emily left me this morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's left before...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's left the room before. She always came  back. Sara nods. Considers this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So. I guess we just divorce our spouses, marry  each other, and have this baby, right? Simple.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Simple. GRADY and Sara stare at the ceiling. Sara sniffs the coat lying beneath her. Miss Sloviak's coat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that Cristaile?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (weary)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My God, I wear the same scent as a  transvestite. She IS a transvestite, isn't:  she?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If she's not now, Terry will make sure she is  by the end of the evening.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Has he asked to see the book yet?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And? Are you going to tell him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. Maybe. I don't know. I don't know what I'm  going to do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (distantly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Neither do 1. GRADY starts to pull up, but his arm is underneath Sara.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sara, my arm. I'm stuck, honey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess you're going to have to chew it off  then.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Poe noses blindly through a forest of legs, pauses by  Miss Sloviak's high heels and scores a Rye Krisp. Crabtre returning with a pair of DRINKS, tiptoes around him, find MISS SLOVIAK chatting with a trim MAN in his 50's.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter! I see you've met my friend.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes . She' s charming.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (taking her drink)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter's been telling me the most fascinating  things about Marilyn Monroe and. ..who was it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe DiMaggio. Simply put, Antonia, it' s my  contention that their marriage tapped into the  very id of American popular culture. Joe  DiMaggio represented, metaphorically speaking,  the Husband as Slugger.. And, though it may be  controversial, I personally believe every  woman, in some way, desires to be Marilyn  Monroe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I couldn't agree more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GRADY works his way through the crowd, spies Walter, and  changes course. Directly ahead is an oddly commanding MAN ("Q"). From the behavior of the people in his vicinity it clear he is someone of interest. Presently, he is putting the make on Hannah Green.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And while my latest has been on the New York  Times bestseller list for 40 weeks, I can't  help but lament that my first book, which  contains what I consider my finest writing, was  remaindered in less than five. So, I find  myself conflicted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ask him if he's conflicted about his house in  the Hamptons.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (brightening)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grady. Q eyes GRADY over his wine glass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello.. .Professor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Q,. Hannah's had two stories published in The  Paris Review. You'd best dust off the 'A'  material for her. As GRADY moves off, he sees Poe sniffing, and goes the  other way, heading directly into the crosshairs of a MAH TWEED, who is talking to another, shorter MAN.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to short man)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A supermarket for the mind, my ass. I'm  telling you, they're nothing but a big, fat mob  laundry. Have you ever been to Davenport, Iowa?  Let me tell you, they need a 30,000-square-foot  bookstore like they need another goddamn cow. (as GRADY passes)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grady!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, Nathan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My God, I haven't seen you since, what? The  PEN/Faulkner Awards. That was a big night for  you, Grady. (to his friend)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GRADY was there for Arsonist's Daughter, The short man blinks, impulsively takes Grady's hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Douglas Triddly, Amherst. I kid you not when I  say Arsonist's Daughter belongs in the pantheon  of late twentieth century fiction. I've had it  on my Graduate Studies syllabus three years  running.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pulling away)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No wonder it's still in print. As GRADY flees, he passes a WOMAN holding a cigarette.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...can take my word for it, writer's are lousy  fucks. Poets aren't bad, but then you've got to  deal with the sweater thing. They'll discover  the cancer in your heart every time, but God  forbid they find a decent dry cleaner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GRADY comes out the back: door and ferrets a JOINT from  his pocket, lights it. He takes a long draw, walks around the side of the house. As he passes a window, a VOICE  accosts him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There you are. GRADY starts, but when he looks through the window, he  sees that the VOICE belongs to WALTER GASKELL and the  person to whom he's talking is Sara. They are standing in the kitchen, near an elaborate WINE RACK.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I could swear I had a '63 Chateau Latour in  here. You haven't seen it, have you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I doubt I'd recognize a '63 Chateau Latour if  I was sitting on it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'd recognize it if you tasted it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I doubt it, darling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (angling & bottle to the light)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, Q certainly will. And, given that he  will be addressing 500 people in little over an  hour...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want to keep him happy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If he' s happy. . . (kissing her as he exits)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm happy. As Walter goes, GRADY studies Sara as she stands alone in the quiet little room, looking small and tired. Finally,  she takes a breath, steeling herself, and moves off,  returning to the clamor inside her house. GRADY sighs, guilt-stricken, then detects a FLICKER of  LIGHT coming from the darkness beyond. A FIGURE is watchi him from the retaining wail that leads to the Gaskell's  garage. GRADY blinks, chagrined that he's been caught  eavesdropping, then his eyes narrow and he steps off the  porch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: James? James Leer wears the same nasty overcoat from class, a  GREEN KNAPSACK hanging off one shoulder. GRADY looks at  what appears to be a sliver of moonlight in James' palm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's fake. James' face betrays his own fragile chagrin and GRADY  peers more closely at what lies in his extended hand. The sliver of moonlight is, in fact, a shiny PEARL-HANDLED  PISTOL.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was my mother's. She won it in a penny  arcade in Baltimore when she was in Catholic  school.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's very convincing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It used to shoot these little paper caps, but  they don't make them anymore. The caps. GRADY reaches for the gun, but James closes his fingers  and slips the tiny thing back into his overcoat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's just. ..for good luck. Some people carry  rabbits' feet...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...You carry firearms. As GRADY exhales a plume of smoke, James' eyes pass  briefly over the jay. GRADY notices, offers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, thank you. I don't like to lose control of  my emotions. GRADY nods, accustomed to James' weirdness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not supposed to be here, in case you were  wondering. I crashed. I mean, not  intentionally... James nods toward the house, where Hannah Green can be  seen in a window, still fending off the determined Q. JAMES LEER (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...but the other night, Hannah and I were  together, at the movies, and she asked me.  Since she was coming. So I ended up coming.  Too. GRADY nods, ponders this over-elaborate explanation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you and Hannah seeing each other, James ?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No! What gave you that idea?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Relax, James. I'm not her father. I just rent  her a room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She likes old movies like I do, that's ail. (glancing back at the window)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Besides, she doesn't really know me. She  thinks she does, but she doesn't. Maybe it's  because she's Mormon and I'm Catholic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe it's because she's beautiful and she  knows it and try as she might to not let that  screw her up, it's inevitable that it will in  some way. James looks away from the window, at Grady.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not like my other teachers, Professor  Tripp.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not like my other students, James. So  what was the movie you two saw?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Huh? Oh. Son or Fury. With Tyrone Power and  Frances Farmer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She went crazy, Frances Farmer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So did Gene Tierney. She's in it too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sounds like a good one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a crooked smile)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not bad. GRADY considers James' fragile face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen, James, about this afternoon. In  workshop. I'm sorry. I think I let things get a  bit out of control.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They really hated it. I think they hated it  more than any of the other ones.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It doesn't matter. It only took me an hour to  write.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (truly impressed)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really? That's remarkable.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have trouble sleeping. While I'm lying in  bed I figure them out. The stories. As James gazes off at the gloaming greenhouse, GRADY  looks down at the left front POCKET of James' overcoat.  Like a nervous tic, James' hand- hidden-twitches against  the modest bulk of the cap gun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You cold, James?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (distant)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A little.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So what are you doing out here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's colder in there. -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (laughing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're right. James blinks, startled by Grady's laughter, startled that he's said something funny. He looks back to the greenhous

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Actually, I saw the greenhouse. So I thought  ...I thought I'd come out here and take a look  at it. You don't see one of those every day. It  looks like heaven...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Heaven?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I saw a movie once. Part of it took place in  heaven. Everyone wore white and lived in  crystal houses. Like that. At least that's the  way I remember it... Abruptly, James glances at his watch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I should be going. James turns away, then stops. He stands like this a  moment, then turns back. Holds out his right hand. JAMES LEER (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goodbye, Professor Tripp. GRADY hesitates, then shakes James' hand. James moves off then, leaving the light of the house behind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: James.  (as he stops)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't leave just yet. There's something I  think you ought to see.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll miss my bus.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is worth it. James looks conflicted. GRADY (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Trust me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's quieter now, the party winding down, as GRADY sneaks the departing guests and toward the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, you two. GRADY stops, sees Hannah slipping on a coat in the foyer. HANNAH GREEN (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you riding with me, James?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I'm going ho--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's going with me. You take Crabtree. And his  friend. All right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ail right. By the way, his friend...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The answer's yes. I think. Yes. I don't know.  Where are they exactly?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here we are! CRABTREE appears at the top of the landing with Miss  Sloviak. Her lipstick is blurry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (spying James)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nell, hello there. CRABTREE steps down the stairs, hand extended. James  Leer's pale fingers rise as if on a string.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: James. This is my editor, Terry Crabtree.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: James'll know about George Sanders.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George Sanders?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. CRABTREE was saying how George Sanders  killed himself, only he couldn't remember how.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pills. August 25, 1972. In a Costa Brava hotel  room. The few people within earshot glance oddly at James, but  Crabtree's eyes glitter with intrigue.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How comprehensive of you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, James is amazing. He knows all the movie  suicides. Go ahead, James. Tell them who else.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's so many...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just a few then. The big ones. James glances at the loose group of people around him,  watching, then...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pier Angeli, 1971 or '72, also pills. Charles  Boyer, 1978, pills again. Charles Butterworth,  1946, I think. In a car. Supposedly it was an  accident, but, you know. . .  (a trace of irony)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He was distraught. Dorothy Dandridge, she took  pills in, like, 1965. Albert Dekker, 1968, he  hung himself. He wrote his suicide note in  lipstick on his stomach. Alan Ladd, '64, more  pills, Carole Landis, pills again, I forget  when. George Reeves, Superman on TV, shot  himself. Jean Seberg/ pills of course, 1979.  Everett Sioane-- he was good--pills. Margaret  Sullavan, pills, Lupe Velez, a lot of pills.  Gig Young. He shot himself and his wife in  1978. There are more but I don't know if you  would have heard of them. Ross Alexander? Clara  Blandick? Maggie McNamara? Gia Scaia?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I haven't heard of half of those.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You did them alphabetically. James turns, finds Crabtree's laser eyes on him. James  blinks, as if he had forgotten about Crabtree, then shrug shyly, looks away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's just how my brain works, I guess.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fascinating. Listen, why don't you come out  with us after the lecture. There's a place on  the Hill I always get Trip to take me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Actually. ..I just want to go home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, don't be silly. No one your age just wants  to go home. Besides, faculty will be present.  Just think of it as a field trip. As he exits, CRABTREE raises an eyebrow to Grady, as if  to say: "Bring him."   MISS SLOVIAK follows, eyeing James glacially as we CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: BLACK
dialogues.text: The dull PURR of a COMBINATION LOCK is HEARD, a DOOR  opens, and a triangle of LIGHT falls on a PHOTOGRAPH of  MARILYN MONROES JOE DIMAGGIO on their wedding day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GRADY and James Leer stand in the doorway. Just below the photograph of Marilyn and Joe--hanging next to a PIN- STRIPED JERSEY bearing the number 5--is a SHORT BLACK SAT JACKET trimmed with an ERMINE COLLAR.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that really it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's really it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The one she wore on her wedding day?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So I'm told. James, in the presence of the holy grail of suicide  garments, stands speechless.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go ahead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really. James swallows, then'-goes to the jacket. Carefully, he  reaches out his fingers and touches the yellowed collar,  barely making contact, as though it might crumble to dust

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're glass. The buttons.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like the lady herself. GRADY says this airily, ironically, riding his buzz a  bit, but James nods solemnly, eyes transfixed on the  jacket, as if Marilyn herself were inside it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She was small. Most people don't know that.  The shoulders are small. (touching the satin)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It looks so perfect. I bet it's the only time  she wore it. That day. She must've felt so  ...happy. GRADY studies James as he takes the fringe of the jacket, lifts it lightly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's feels unreal, like butterfly wings or...  something. It must've cost Dr. Gaskell a lot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess. Walter never tells Sara the truth  about how much he pays for these things.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're really good friends with the  Chancellor, aren't you? Grady's eyes slide, paranoid, but James' face remains  unchanged, consumed with the jacket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (carefully)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pretty good. I'm friends with Dr. Gaskell,  too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess you must be, if you know the  combination to his closet and he doesn't mind  your being here in their bedroom like this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right. A DOOR SLAMS downstairs and GRADY and James jump. The  CLICK of a woman's HIGH HEELS sends GRADY to the bedroom  window, where he watches Sara slide into a WHITE CITROEN  DS23, turn on the ignition, and motor away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We, better skedaddle. Close that closet--  James? You ail right? James is slumped on the Gaskell's white linen bed,  knapsack between his knees, head in hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry. Professor Tripp. Maybe it's seeing  that jacket that belonged to her. It just  looks...really lonely. Hanging there. In a  closet. Maybe I'm just a little sad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe. I'm feeling a little sad myself  tonight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mean, with your wife leaving you and ail?  (off Grady's look)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hannah mentioned something about it.   About a  note.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. Well. It's complicated, James. I think we  should go now. Without thinking, GRADY flicks out the bedroom light,  leaving James Leer in the dark for the second time today. James just sits there, a shadow in a room of shadows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A LOW RUMBLE freezes GRADY as he enters the hail. A few feet away, Poe lies belly to the ground, his blind blue eyes trained, more or less, in Grady's direction.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. Easy now. Eee-zy. . . . GRADY starts to take a step, when.... Poe shoots forward  and sinks himself deep into Grady's ankle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus! GRADY hops gracelessly, momentarily lifting Poe off the  ground as he swings his leg up. Poe, countering, rolls hi head in a snapping motion and drops GRADY in a clumsy hea

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get off of me, you son-of-a-bitch! Poe regains his feet, but doesn't let go, whipping his  head back and forth, back and forth, over and over,  growling low, dark, and hideously from the back of his  throat, until there is a sharp...

dialogues.speaker: CRACK
dialogues.text: Poe YELPS, goes perfectly still, then topples heavily  onto Grady's legs. GRADY turns. James Leer stands in the doorway, posed with the  little pearl-handled pistol like Steve McQueen. GRADY looks at James. Then Poe. Then back to James.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shit, James. You shoe Dr. Gaskell's dog.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I had to. Didn't I?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Couldn't you've just pulled him off me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No! He was crazy. I didn't-he looked-- 1  thought --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, okay. Take it easy. Don't freak out on  me. GRADY roils down his sock. Apparently, Poe went through  life with a slight overbite.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you have a mirror? It's the best way to see  if someone's breathing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's dead, James. Believe me, I know a dead  dog when I see one. James looks miserably at Poe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are we going to do? GRADY rises awkwardly, holds out his hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: First you're going to give me that little cap  gun of yours.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GRADY and James stare gloomily out the windshield.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Professor Tripp? Can I  ask you a question?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yea, James.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are we going to do with... James glances in the backseat, where Poe lies, strange  blue eyes gleaming.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. I'm still trying to figure out  how to tell the Chancellor I murdered her  husband's dog.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Trust me, James, when the family pet's been  assassinated, the owner doesn't want to hear  one of her students was the triggerman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Does she want to hear it was one of her  professors?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've got tenure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As sporadic APPLAUSE wafts from the high windowpanes of  Thaw Hall, GRADY leans into the Galaxie's trunk, creates space between the tuba and a ZIPPERED SUITCASE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. James totters forward, arms hooked under Poe's front legs looking like a sorry marathon dancer. GRADY frowns, limps forward, and takes the hind legs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's still a little warm. They lay him down, push him deep into the trunk--until  there is a SOUND like a pencil SNAPPING.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yuck. GRADY grabs Crabtree's garment bag, frisks the pockets.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's a. big trunk. It fits a tuba, a  suitcase, a dead dog, and a garment bag almost  perfectly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (searching)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's just what they used to say in the ads.  Come on, Crabtree, I know you're holding...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whose tuba is that anyway?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miss Sloviak's.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I ask you something about her?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She is. Ah. Here we go... GRADY unravels a pair of boxer shorts, finds an airplane- size bottle of JACK DANIELS, then grabs another pair of  boxers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh. So. Is--is your friend Crabtree-- is he-- gay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Most of the time he is, James. Some of the  time he isn't. Now what do we have here? GRADY rattles a prescription bottle, then shakes out a  pair of WHITE PILLS, each etched with a tiny numeral 3.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Looks like ...our old friend Mr. Codeine. That  should take the pinch out of my ankle. (handing the bottle to James)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No thanks. I'm fine without them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right. That's why you were standing in the  Chancellor's back yard twirling that little cap  gun of yours tonight.  You're fine, all right,  you're fit as a fucking fiddle. GRADY opens the tiny bottle of Jack with his teeth,  drinks down two number 3's, then looks at James.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, James. I'm sorry I said that. Recklessly, James takes a pill, tosses it in his mouth,  and tips back the tiny bottle of Jack. Half a second late he spits it all out. GRADY looks down, peels the soggy pi from the lapel of his jacket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How 'bout we try that again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On the stage. Walter Gaskell stands alone at a podium.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...really needs no introduction. Walk down the  aisle of any airplane or by the pool of any  hotel and you'll see his face beaming back at  you. You all know the name, you all know the  books, so welcome if you will, the man those of  us who know him simply call.. .Q. As the audience THUNDERS, GRADY and James slink into the  auditorium. It's standing room only. As they head for an  open space against the back wail, GRADY squeezes past a K with a GOATEE .who regards him warily.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good evening. GRADY stares, over the gleaming sea of heads before him,  watching as Q pauses, ..for a very long moment... waiting until the auditorium is consumed in a heavy, anticipatory hush. Finally, he speaks again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am a writer. As the audience EXPLODES with glee, GRADY frowns. He  glances to his right, sees James' left brow crinkled with similar look of bafflement. Q (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As a writer, one thing you learn is that  everyone you encounter has a story. Every  bartender, every taxi driver, everybody has an  idea or a. story that would make a "great book"  or a "great movie." Presumably, each of you has  an idea. (gestures to the audience) But, how do you go from there to here? How do  you go from having an idea to having a book?  How do you get across? What is the bridge, the  bridge that allows you to walk on air from the  shoreline of inspiration to the terra firma of  accomplishment? Faith. Faith that your story is  worth the telling, faith that you have the  wherewithal to tell it, faith that the  carefully woven structure you create won't  collapse beneath you... GRADY glances at James, sees that his eyes are unblinking and glazed, then sees, beyond him, Sara standing by the f EXIT. A blink later, she is gone. Q (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...and faith that when you get to the other  side someone will be waiting who gives a damn  about the tale you have to tell. GRADY leans back, listening to the BEATING of his own  HEART, the soft GLIMMER of the chandeliers hanging by a  thread forty feet above his head... Abruptly, James LAUGHS OUT LOUD--some private amusement:  bubbling up from the bottom or his brain and out into the auditorium. As Q looks and four hundred other heads turn, James ducks down--mortified. Crabtree, sitting a few rows away, studies James with amusement, then winks at Grady. GRADY blinks, turns to James.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll be right back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GRADY bursts through the auditorium doors and into the  lobby. A PAIR. of local BOOKSELLERS, chatting quietly  behind a table arrayed with the BOOKS of attending author glance up as GRADY limps toward the restrooms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GRADY stumbles down the sloping carper, but the corridor  begins to turn sideways on him and he stops, resting his  cheek against the cool...cool...wall. ..as...ail..-goes..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grady? Grady? GRADY opens his eyes, finds Sara's face swimming above  him. He is lying on his back in the corridor, his corduro blazer bundled under his head like a pillow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You had another one, didn't you? You have to  see a doctor, Grady. First thing Monday  morning. All right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is the thing-is it over?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Almost. Wane to sit up? (as he winces)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the matter?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing. I think I twisted my-- GRADY looks at his ankle and feels a rush of guilt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have to tell you something. Something..  .hard. Sara's face stiffens, becomes more Chancelloresque.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then stand up. I'm too old for all this  roiling around on the floor. GRADY lets her pull him up, watches her light a  cigarette.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't. I know what you're going to say.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, really, Sara, I don't think you--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You love Emily. I know that. And you need to  stay with her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think I really have a choice in, that.  Emily left me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She'll come back. That's why I'm going to.  ..to not have this baby. GRADY watches her flip her hand up, bring the cigarette  to her lips, and inhale ...then grimace and drop it to th floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not have it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. There's no way. I mean, don't you think  there's no way?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, no, I don't see any way. (taking her hand)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I know how hard it is for you to-- to lose  this chance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (jerking away)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No you don't. And fuck you for saying you do.  And fuck you for "saying. . . (quietly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...for saying there's just no way. Because  there could be a way, Grady. Somewhere deep in the building, APPLAUSE swells.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (composing herself)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He must be finishing. We should go. GRADY looks sadly at Sara then stoops to retrieve his  coat.  As he grabs it, James Leer's little pistol CLATTER to the floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who's gun is that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's-it's a souvenir. Of Baltimore. Before GRADY can close his hand, Sara has it in her own.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Heavy. Smells like gunpowder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Caps. She points it-at Grady's chest. He smiles nervously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I love you, Grady. GRADY places his fingers gently over Sara's... and  removes the gun from her hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I love you, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The auditorium doors swing open and James Leer emerges,  arms draped over CRABTREE and a LARGE STUDENT.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Woah! The doors made so much noise! As they make for the restrooms, Sara and GRADY appear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is so embarrassing! You guys had to carry  me out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is he ail right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (rolling his eyes)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's fine. He's narrating.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're going to the men's room. Only we might  not make it in time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Terry CRABTREE and James Leer. Leave it to you  to make that mistake, wait here. As Sara heads off after James, GRADY turns toward the  lobby...directly into the hostile gaze of Miss Sloviak.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I need a ride.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm your man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the Galaxie's big trunk yawns open. MISS SLOVIAK  stares at what's wedged up against her suitcase.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's an explanation. MISS SLOVIAK raises an eyebrow and then, leaning in,  unzips her suitcase.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As GRADY drives, MISS SLOVIAK finishes with the top  button of a man's shirt, then reaches into the zippered  COSMETICS BAG in her lap. Onto the open tray of the  glovebox, she places a JAR of COLD CREAM, a BOTTLE of NAI POLISH REMOVER, and a cloud of COTTON BALLS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Couldn't he have just thrown a shoe at the  poor thing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: James is. ..I don't know...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Disturbed. And when your friend CRABTREE gets  done with him, he's going to be even more  disturbed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not sure that's possible.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure it is. GRADY watches MISS SLOVIAK peel the wig from her  forehead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen, Antonia--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tony. Now that I'm home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tony. I'm sorry if things didn't work out so  well for you tonight. With Terry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forget it. I should've known better. Your  friend is just, I don't know, into collecting  weird tricks. Mind? Tony angles the rearview mirror toward himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's writing his name in water.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like most editors, he really wants to be a  writer, but he's too busy living a novel to  bother writing one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That sounds like a fancy excuse for being a  shit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He'd call it habit. But now. ..I get the  feeling he's going through the motions a bit. Tony peels off a pair of false eyelashes, blinks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mean because his career's ruined and all?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus. Is that what he told you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He said he hasn't had a success in ten years  and everyone in New York thinks he's kind of  .a. . . As Tony re-sets the rearview mirror, GRADY gets a glimpse of his own swollen eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...loser. But I'm sure your book is so good  that he'll be able to keep his job. Hearing this, GRADY looks troubled. MISS SLOVIAK points.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Turn here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GRADY pulls in front of a small brick house. On the front lawn, a small statue of the BLESSED VIRGIN stands under a little white BAND SHELL painted with stars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That'' s nice. All we have is a Japanese  beetle trap.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a bathtub. What she's standing under. The PORCH LIGHT conies on and a SMALL, WHITE-HAIRED MAN  squints through the screen door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's Pop.  (turning)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me see it. The gun. GRADY reaches into his pocket, hands it over. Tony  smirks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Figures. It's like the kind of gun Bette Davis  would carry. In a little beaded purse? GRADY studies the gun in Tony's hand, then glances at the front screen door. Pop is still there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd better go. I think I may have to rescue  James Leer. MISS SLOVIAK returns the gun, .steps out of the car, and  peers in at Grady.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, Grady, if I were you. I'd think  about going home. You look like you need a  little rescuing yourself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GRADY parks near a VAN that has KRAVNIK'S SPORTING GOODS  stenciled on the side. He watches a BOUNCER frisk a patro in the PINK LIGHT of the Hi-Hat Club's entrance, then  slides -James Leer's little PISTOL into the glovebox.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As GRADY steps to the door, the bouncer gives him a  perfunctory pat-down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (kidding him)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clean tonight, hub, Professor?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As a whistle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hannah Green is dancing with a sweat-drenched Q as GRADY  enters this SMOKE-FILLED RHYTHM AND BLUES club. She becko with a finger, but Grady--Nervous at the sight of her  glistening Mormon skin--merely pantomimes an exaggerated  shrug and she points. CRABTREE and James Leer sit at a dark corner table. James slouches, eyes half-closed, while CRABTREE stares in the  general vicinity of the dancers, his hand extended beneat the table, in the general vicinity of James' lap. Grady, looking a little alarmed, grabs a passing  WAITRESS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Double Dickel on the rocks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As GRADY arrives, CRABTREE withdraws his hand delicately  and James' eyes flutter open .briefly, ..then close.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that just beer?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Primarily. Although I gather you two staged a  little raid on the CRABTREE pharmacopoeia. You  missed a few bottles, by the way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sure. Where is everyone?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sara and Walter declined. Guess they wanted to  go home and curl up on the couch with the dog. GRADY cuts James a glance, trying to determine if he's  copped on Poe, but James is winking out. His head drifts  back against the wail, settles with a gentle ...thunk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus. He's out. CRABTREE glances over, nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He has a book.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know. He started it Fall semester.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He finished it Winter Break. GRADY looks up, unable to disguise his surprise.  He  glances at James' slack face tilted against the wall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So. Is he any good?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. Not yet he isn't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I'm going to read it anyway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on. Crabs. Don't do this. He's . one oВЈ  my students, for Christ sake. I'm not even sure  if he's-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is. Take my word for it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think it's more complicated than that.  Besides, he's a little...scattered. He almost  ...did something stupid tonight. At least, I  think so. Anyway, he doesn't need sexual  confusion thrown into the stew right now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On the contrary, it 'could be just the ticket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (ducking in)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Double Dickel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks. GRADY notices the waitress's nametag (OOLA) and realizes  she is conspicuously PREGNANT. He watches her disappear  beyond the blur of bodies on the dancefloor, where Hannah Green's slinky form seizes his attention.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No sexual confusion there, eh, Professor?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shut up and drink. CRABTREE grins, brings his bottle up, then stops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh my goodness. Do you see what I see? GRADY follows Crabtree's glance and finds Oola again, but it's not Oola CRABTREE is eyeing, it's her CUSTOMER.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: President of the James Brown Hair Club For  Men. Sitting alone in the dark booth is a SMALL BLACK MAN with big hands, a face peppered with scar tissue, and--most  noticeably--a tsunami of hair sprouting from his scalp.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (initiating an old game)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's a boxer. A flyweight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Huh uh. A jockey. His name's, um, Curtis..  .Curtis Hardapple.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not Curtis.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vernon, then. Vernon Hardapple. The scar's are  from a--from a horse. He fell during a race and  got trampled.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And now he's addicted to painkillers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He can't piss standing up anymore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He lives with his mother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And he had a younger brother who . . .was . .  . a. . .

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Groom. Named Claudell.  And his mother blames  Vernon for his death.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (stumped)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because. . .because. . .

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sleepily)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: .. .he was killed, when a gangster named  Freddie Nostrils tried to shoot his favorite  horse. He took the bullet himself. GRADY and Crabtree turn to look at James Leer, who opens  one bloodshot eye to regard them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vernon, over there, was in on the hit. James' eye closes. CRABTREE looks over at Grady.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That was good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He heard everything we were saying. Just then, Hannah Green bounces up in her red boots.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on. Teach. I want you to dance with me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GRADY and Hannah, reflected in bits and pieces in the  jack 'o lantern wail of MIRRORED TILE, slow-dance to a  sexy, measured blues.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've been re-reading Arsonist's Daughter. It's  so beautiful, Grady. So natural. It's like ail  your sentences always existed, just waiting  around in Style Heaven, or wherever, for you to  fetch them down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I love the inscription you wrote to me.  Only I'm not quite the downy innocent you think  I am.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hope that isn't true. We need all the downy  innocents we can get. GRADY spies the corner table, watches CRABTREE say  something to Q and then, casually, stroke a lock of hair  from James Leer's forehead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So what are you going to do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just mean, I--I guess Emily isn't going to  be there when you get home. GRADY looks down into Hannah's translucent face, then  catches a glimpse of himself in the fractured, wail. The  tile that would reflect his head is missing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you holding me up or am I dragging you  down? Hannah snuggles closer, lays her head on Grady's chest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shush.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grady, limping on his bad ankle, carries James to  Hannah's rumpled RENAULT, props him against the fender.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, Hannah. When you get him home ...make  sure he's ail right. Before you leave. Okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I would if I knew where I was taking him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hannah, are you telling me you don't know  where James Leer lives?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some apartment somewhere. But I've never seen  it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That strikes me as odd.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: James is odd. I know he has an aunt in  Sewickley Heights. I dropped him there once,  but...  (remembering)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come to think of it, it-wasn't even his Aunt's  house. He said she worked there. Or something.  I don't remember. James MUMBLES, starts to slide onto the hood of the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mmhmmm.. . . knap ...sap....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's he saying?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His bag. You know that ratty green thing he's  always carrying around. He must've left it  inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hh-uh. Last time I saw it was... GRADY glances at the idling Galaxie across the street.

dialogues.speaker: CRABTREE
dialogues.text: and Q huddle inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shit. He must've left it back at Thaw. In the  auditorium.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (delirious, but insistent)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mmrrmmm.. .KNAP SAP! GRADY frowns in annoyance, opens the passenger door. GRADY (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right. Take him to my place. He can crash  on the sofa.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The one in your office? It's the best one .for  naps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think it really matters, Hannah. We  could probably stand him up in the garage with  the snow shovels at this point. As GRADY lowers James into the seat, he WHIMPERS, curls  into a bail. Hannah turns her puppy dog eyes on Grady.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ail right. In my office. As GRADY starts to turn away, Hannah's fingers graze his  face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey. If you want to talk later...I'll be up. GRADY watches her fold her lovely self into the car and  drive away. He sighs, crosses to the Galaxie, and just ha his hand on the doorhandle when a TINY FIGURE appears. Vernon Hardapple.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You driving this car?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This 1966 maroon Ford Galaxie 500. You driving  this car?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's mine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bullshit. It's mine, motherfucker.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You must be mistaken.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bullshit. GRADY shakes his head wearily, opens the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go home to your mother, Vernon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GRADY slides in next to Q, puts the car in gear, and  starts to pull away. As he glances in the rearview, he se CRABTREE smiling darkly in the backseat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, what's the matter? CRABTREE just keeps smiling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Christ, Crabs, what do you expect me to do?  The kid's practically in a coma.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tripp.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hit your brakes. GRADY flicks his eyes from the rearview mirror just as a  SHADOW looms in his headlights. As he squashes the break  pedal, Q's EYEGLASSES go flying into the windshield.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (squinting)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh my God! What is that? It's Vernon, waving his arms, his shadow enormous in the  beams of light.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's this guy's problem?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just go around him. GRADY taps the accelerator, but each time, Vernon dances  back in front of Grady's grille.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Back up. Go out the other way. GRADY throws the car in reverse, backs straight up, then  turns up a one-way street. He shoots down the alley behin the Hi-Hat, turns onto the adjoining street, ..and watche in amazement as Vernon materializes from behind the high  wooden fence that runs parallel to the Galaxie. As GRADY pinches the brakes, Vernon grins.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (mischievously)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You could always go over him. Then, as the three men watch, Vernon rocks back on his  heels and--with a gymnast's precision-pitches himself ont the Galaxie's big hood. He -lands on his ass, slides  smoothly off, then takes a deep bow and disappears into t night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What just happened? GRADY peers at the wrinkled asterisk on his hood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just had my car jumped on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grady stops the car in the red zone and gets out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait here. I'll be right back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where would we go?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The JANITOR, the same shaggy-haired kid GRADY saw rigging the WordFest banner earlier, is struggling with a balky  FLOOR WAXER as GRADY steps up to the double doors and sla his hand against the glass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's open. GRADY pushes on the door and it opens. JANITOR (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Professor Tripp.  (off Grady's look)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Traxler. Sam. I took your class freshman year.  Then I dropped out of school.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hope it wasn't my fault.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (taking him seriously)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. I guess you're here for the backpack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh.. .yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The knapsack is sitting on one of the metal folding  chairs as Sam and GRADYenter the silent hail.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I saw the manuscript inside. So when you  showed up, I figured. . . GRADY lifts the knapsack, peers inside. There is no title page to the MANUSCRIPT, Just the words The Love Parade an then, halfway down, TEXT.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is it good?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reading)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. It might be...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GRADY steps outside, closes the flap of the knapsack and, hunching his shoulders against the cold... stops. Crabtree. Q. The car. Gone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Traxler gives GRADY a ride in his Honda, one of the  original Hondas best suited for sidewalk driving. The  backseat bulges with a huge AMPLIFIER and BASS GUITAR.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Say, Professor Tripp, is ail that stuff true  about Errol Flynn? How he used to put coke on  his dick. To make himself, you know, like, last  longer?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Christ, Traxler. How the hell should I know?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, jeez, you're reading his biography,  aren't you? Sam points and GRADY glances at the knapsack riding on  the seat between him and Sam. A BOOK'-bearing ERROL FLYNN PICTURE--IS tucked into the side pouch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, right. Yeah, that's true. He used to rub  ail kinds of things on it. Paprika. Ground  lamb.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sam brings the car to a coughing idle across the street  from the Gaskell's house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wow, check out that greenhouse. Is that your  wife? GRADY gazes at Sara, a .vaporous blur in the greenhouse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, my wife's out of town. Just then, the Honda FILLS WITH LIGHT. HEADLIGHTS loom,  then a POLICE CAR sweeps into the Gaskell's driveway.  Walter appears on the front steps. TRAXLER (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who's that guy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her husband. Traxler looks anxiously at the police car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What exactly are we doing here, Professor  Tripp?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (staring at Sara)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Taking the long way home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Traxler drives away, GRADY mounts the porch with James Leer's knapsack hanging from one shoulder. He reaches abo the door, feeling for a key, but his fingers come away wi only dust. He stands, dispirited, then an idea strikes. H takes the doorknob, turns it. It opens.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GRADY enters, closes the door quietly behind him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The room is dim but the TV is on, throwing crazy slashes  of light onto the wails and ceiling. As GRADY limps by, h finds a sleeping Hannah Green, bundled in a blanket, T- shirt, and little else. On the floor, near her dangling  hand, Woolf's A Common Reader lays open next to a Diet  Coke. GRADY considers the smooth geography of her body, b his eyes 'are most powerfully drawn to. ..her feet. He  steps forward, lifts the blanket gently, but finds-to his disappointment--only the red cowboy boots. He picks up the remote, turns off the TV, and exits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: James Leer slumbers on a green sofa, draped in an old  sleeping bag. GRADY drops behind his desk, lets James'  knapsack slide to the floor. He lifts his cuff, inspects  his ugly ankle, then glimpses something in the knapsack. Something yellow. Something soft. GRADY reaches down and, slowly--like a magician producing a magical scarf-extracts MARILYN MONROE'S WEDDING JACKET  from James Leer's ratty green knapsack.  GRADY glances at the young man on his sofa, then, looking very tired, reaches for the desk lamp ...and turns out th light on the both of them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GRADY steps outside in a WOMAN'S CHENILLE BATHROBE and  plucks the Pittsburgh Post-Gazette from the second porch  step. He fishes out a charred ROACH, starts to light it,  then notices the Galaxie sitting in the driveway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As CRABTREE SNORES thunderously, GRADY eases open the  door, spots the CAR KEYS on the dresser, grabs them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GRADY eases the door shut, starts to turn, then stops,  his eyes drawn to the door just across the landing from  Crabtree's room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GRADY pushes open the door with the tips of his fingers,  lets it glide open. The room that is revealed is bright a well-ordered, in direct contrast to the lazy clutter of  Grady's office. There is a DRAFTING TABLE and a COMPUTER, pads and pens neatly arranged alongside. A BULLITEN BOARD hangs on one wall, bearing an intricate  mosaic of multi-colored index cards. There are PRINTS,  framed, from various art exhibits, and two of Grady's  DHSTJACKETS--including, most prominently, Arsonist's  Daughter. There are PHOTOGRAPHS of EMILY too. In a black turtleneck with friends. In a sundress with Grady. In a billowing  Burberry, floating like a dark butterfly against a BLUR o YELLOW TAXIS on a street in Manhattan. Smiling brilliantly. Beautiful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GRADY enters with a THERMOS--pauses--redistributes the  sleeping bag over James Leer's pale body.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (without waking)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're welcome. GRADY sits at his desk, pours himself a cup of coffee  from the thermos, then sets the cup directly in the cente of a galaxy of previous coffee rings. Next, he takes a  clean piece of paper, balls it up, and-with ritual  precision-strokes it into the MINIATURE BASKETBALL HOOP  that crowns the rim of the WASTE BASKET across the room. All net. A 9-VOLT CROWD ROAR belches from the hoop and, without  further ceremony, GRADY turns to the blank page curling from his IBM SELECTRIC  and SPACES to the top right corner, TYPES: (beat) 2611 In other words: Page 2611. CLOSE UP - THE TYPEWRITER PAPER -- darkening with WORDS,  the KEYS SNAPPING faster and faster, a CRAZY CLAMOR that  grows and grows until, finally, it just ....Stops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: James I   GRADY awakes with his back to the floor, James leer's  quizzical face floating like a cloud above him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm okay. I just lost my balance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I put you on the floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought you might--l don't know-- swallow  your tongue or something. (nodding to Grady's robe)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess you really miss her, huh? GRADY peers down at the geraniums blooming on the pockets of the robe, its overall fuzziness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Huh? Oh, no. This isn't Emily's. I just write  in it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess there's probably a story behind that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is, but it's not that interesting. James nods. Down the hallway, in another room, the  TELEPHONE RINGS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Want me to get that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure. As James shuffles away in the sleeping bag, GRADY rises  delicately and turns toward the window, ..just in time to see a POLICE CAR roil slowly by on the screen below.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (returning)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He didn't give his name.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The guy on the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What'd he say?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He wanted to know if a GRADY Trip? lived here  and drove a dark maroon 1966 Ford Galaxie 500  with black interior.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What'd you tell him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good, James. If the Zodiac killer calls, be  sure to mention the back door pops open with a  couple hard shakes to the right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought maybe you'd won a radio contest or  something. Is that single-spaced? James has noticed the towering stack of 20 Ib. bond on  Grady's desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Afraid so.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's a big book you're writing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think it's sort of writing itself at this  point.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wow, Hannah always swore you were working,  but--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But . . . ?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing, it's just that,, well, it's been  awhile since Arsonist's Daughter, and some  people--some of the kids in workshop--thought  maybe you were...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Washed up?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Blocked.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah. I don't believe in writer's block. James takes another glance at the mammoth manuscript.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No kidding. A LOUD HACKING is HEARD. GRADY and James turn, watch  Crabtree, wearing only a pair of striped boxers,  materialize in the hallway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good morning, boys. James. James waves feebly from beneath the sleeping bag.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (re: James' "attire")

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If-you 're planning on staying for breakfast,  I'd put on something a little less comfortable  if I were you. As GRADY moves to his desk to reacquaint himself with the page curling from the typewriter, James continues to star into the emptiness of the hallway. The sight of CRABTREE  seems to have made him suddenly queasy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Professor Tripp?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How did I get here last night?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No one seems to know where you live, James.  Hannah thought you'd like my couch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And ...and before that. Did I do anything?  Anything bad?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
