dialogues.text: Well, James, you did shoot the Head of the  English Department's dog and steal his most  prized piece of memorabilia. As James contemplates this, the DOORBELL RINGS. GRADY  looks up, sees the POLICE CAR he noticed earlier, now  parked at the bottom of his driveway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do yourself a favor, James ...Hide.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A POLICEMAN not much older than James Leer waits. As the  door opens, GRADY appears.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good morning...  (eyeing Grady's robe)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Professor Tripp? Sorry to bother you, sir, but  I understand you attended an event at Sara and  Walter Gaskell's house last night and were one  of the last to leave...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: James lurks at the top of the stairs, swaddled in the  sleeping bag, straining to hear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...was just wondering if maybe you saw anyone.  Someone you didn't know. Who seemed out of  place. Suspicious maybe...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GRADY is  scratching his head in mock thought.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, there's always people you don't know at  these things, but I can't say there was anybody  particularly suspicious. ..Wait. There was one  guy. Tiny fella. Claimed to be a jockey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A jockey? You mean, like--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Horses, right. Vernon something... (thinking... )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hardpple Pupcik stops on his pad, looks up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hardapple?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I could be wrong. What happened anyway?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Huh? Oh, someone pulled a B&E on Dr. Gaskell's  closet. And the dog's missing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's weird.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We figure the perpetrator let him out. He's  blind and we figure he just wandered off and  got run over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The perpetrator.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, the dog.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just kidding. Pupcik nods slowly, as if re-filing GRADY under "Dealing  With Assholes."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One other thing. About this kid, this student  of yours- Leer--James Leer. You wouldn't know  how I could get in touch with him, would you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I might have his number on campus.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's all right. We'll find him. Pete Pupcik smiles, tips his big blue police hat, and  turns away. GRADY frowns, starts to close the door...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There you are... GRADY stiffens, then turns to find Hannah Green across  the room in her t-shirt and cowboy boots, looking ail dew eyed and delectable.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought we were going to talk. Last night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh. Well. I... Hannah stretches and the t-shirt slides dangerously up  her thighs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's okay. ..I'm here when you want me. GRADY stands frozen as Hannah smiles sleepily, pushes  through the swinging door into the kitchen. A THUMPING is heard as James, tangled in the sleeping bag, hitches down the last few steps of the stairway. He watches Pete Pupci drive away in his big police car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do we do now? #####Before GRADY can reply, .the TELEPHONE sitting on th #####RINGS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grady, it's Sara. Thank God you're there. You  won't believe what's happened.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Could you hold on a minute, honey? With a look of wonderment, GRADY watches his hand ever- so- gently ...hang up the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How 'bout we get the hell out of here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: James, now wearing one of Grady's flannel shirts beneath  his ratty overcoat, follows Grady-to the Galaxie, knapsac swinging from his shoulder. GRADY tosses him a ring of  KEYS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You start her up. As GRADY runs a plastic WEDGE over the GLAZE of ice  blanketing the windshield, James stares curiously at the  keys, as if they were some strange artifact, then slides  behind the steering wheel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as the engine roars)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How's that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well done, James. As GRADY works, James' face comes into view, then ...the  wedge SNAPS, splintering into the flesh of Grady's hand. GRADY (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shit! James blinks, pokes his head out the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're bleeding. Professor Tripp.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GRADY and James stand in the sundries aisle of a  neighborhood MARKET. GRADY has a TIN of BAND-AIDS open and is presently plastering  his ragged thumb.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where exactly do you live, James? James, in the midst of chugging from a 64-OUNCE JUG of  ORANGE JUICE, stops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Apparently not even Hannah Green has a clue as  to the location of your apartment. GRADY tosses the tin of band-aids into a small plastic  hand basket, begins to move down the aisle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got kicked out. Well, not exactly kicked  out. I was asked to leave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess there's probably a story behind that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is, but it's not that interesting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So where have you been staying?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a long pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bus station. GRADY stares incredulously at James.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not -so bad. I know the night janitor.  And there's a broken locker I can put my stuff.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (trying to fathom this)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But James. I mean. ..How long?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A couple weeks. That's why... that's why I had  the gun. For protection.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus, James, you should've told someone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know... (unconvincingly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Me. GRADY drops the basket at the check-out counter and,  abruptly, finds himself face to face with a BABY, lolling on the shoulder of the woman before him. The baby is  staring, spellbound, at a display of...Q'S LATEST

dialogues.speaker: PAPERBACK. GRADY
dialogues.text: frowns, then detects the true source of enchantment: a  spray of SHINY MYLAR GIFT BALLOONS. A thought evolves. GRADY (cont'd) (the balloons)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you think of these? James takes another chug from his jug, nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grady, squinting through the ten-inch panel of cleared  ice on the windshield, roils slowly up onto the curb in  front of Walter and Sara Gaskell's house ...then off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GRADY pops the glovebox, takes out a PEN, and scratches  something on the GIFT CARD attached to the BALLOON. James glances briefly at a plump ZIPLOC OF POT stashed in the  glovebox, then peers at the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (the house)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Isn't this...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hm. GRADY gets out, then pauses, glancing at the giant orange juice jug between James legs. It's about half-down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You better ease off that stuff, James. It's  pretty acidic. James takes a powdered donut that lies on his coat,  studies it curiously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't help myself. I don't know what's the  matter with me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shit, James, you're hungover. What do you  think's the matter with you? As GRADY turns away, James ponders this, then considers  the ring of white sugar imprinted on his coat and re-sets the donut in precisely the same place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Through the steamy panes, we SEE GRADY approach with the  balloon, enter. He crosses to a high table, sets the  balloon down, and steps back, considering the placement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Feeling guilty? GRADY jumps--startled--and turns. Sara has materialized  behind a ficus, large POTTING GLOVES on her hands. SARA (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't believe you hung up on me, you dick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Totally.  I'm sorry. A lot was happening this  morning. Can you talk? Sara nods, moves the ficus to another table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter's on campus, being the good soldier for  WordFest. But he's a basket case. Someone stole  Marilyn's jacket last night. And Poe's missing,  too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I-heard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You heard? How?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A twelve-year-old policeman came by the house  this morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you confess? GRADY looks up, mildly alarmed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your fingerprints were all over the bedroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really? That was fast.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (frowning)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm kidding. Hello?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh. Right. Ha. Listen, about last night. There  is something I need to tell...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you limping? Why are you limping?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hub? Oh, well, that's part of what I need to .  . .

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you pass out again, Grady? Did you fall  somewhere?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. I mean. Well, actually, yes. Sort of. I  don't remember. Listen, Sara, I have to tell  you something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right. Sara settles back, folds her arms. Waiting.

dialogues.speaker: I...
dialogues.text: As GRADY stares into Sara's eyes, things begin to blur.  GRADY (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...want to be with you. Sara looks at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gee, Grady, that sounded so heartfelt.  I  don't know whether to swoon or smirk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really, Sara, I... Sara holds up one gloved hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I believe you. I believe you want to be with  me. But this is not just about me anymore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know that. I know what's at stake here...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I don't think you do. And besides... I  haven't decided yet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: About the baby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That ...and you. GRADY goes still, watches Sara strip off the gloves, drop them on  a table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not going to draw the map for you on this  one, Grady. Times like these you have to do  your own navigating. Sara turns to leave, then stops, squinting far down the  street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who's that sitting in your car?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: James Leer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's he doing out there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sort of helping him work through some  issues. Sara raises an eyebrow, then pushes through the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Isn't he lucky. GRADY watches her ripple across the glass, head for the  house, and wave. James, slumped low in the Galaxie, offer a limp hand in return, but it's too late. She's already gone.

dialogues.speaker: LATER 54
dialogues.text: GRADY cradles the wheel in his bandaged paw, while James  sits stiffly, the orange juice jug bobbing between his  thighs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She seemed to take it pretty well.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, well, actually. . . James looks over. GRADY (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The moment didn't really present itself. James nods, unsurprised, then turns back to the window,  staring at the landscape, still sitting oddly still. GRAD glances at him. At the orange juice jug. GRADY (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You' re not planning on puking in my car, are  you, James? Nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't be proud, James. We're in Sewickley  Heights. We could find you a nice golf course  to barf on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sharply)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. GRADY looks over, surprised by the James' tone. James  blinks, looks embarrassed. JAMES LEER (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean. I'm fine. I'm sorry. I just... James peers out the window at passing landscape. JAMES LEER (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've got a thing about, ..places like this. I  know what those houses are like. I know what  the people are like.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your aunt ? James turns, eyes flashing with surprise. GRADY (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hannah mentioned something about an aunt. James nods vaguely, then reaches into the ashtray, takes  a JOINT between his fingers, sniffs it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Humboldt County?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (surprised)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's my father. He gets it from his doctor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Glaucoma?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Colon cancer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus, James. Wow. James puts the joint back in the ashtray.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a bit of a scandal. My parents live in a  small town.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where's that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carvel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carvel? Where's Carvel?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Outside Scranton.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I never heard of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a hellhole. Three motels and a mannequin  factory. My dad worked there for thirty-five  years.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your father worked in a mannequin factory?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seitz Plastics. That's where he met my morn.  She was a fry cook in the cafeteria. Before  that, she'd been a dancer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What kind of dancer? .

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whatever kind they wanted her to be.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in disbelief)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: James Leer, are you telling me your mother was  a stripper?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm telling you what I was told by my uncle.  And he should know. He ran half a dozen men's  clubs in Baltimore before he skipped town on a  bad debt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Didn't you say your Mom went to Catholic  school?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When we fall, we fall hard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Amazing. GRADY takes the joint from the ashtray, lights it, then  notices-with surprise--James has his hand out. GRADY (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought you were the guy who didn't like to  lose control of his emotions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe I just needed the moment to present  itself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GRADY glides down the graceful, tree-lined streets of a  modest, but well-kept neighborhood. James still has the  JOINT-now only a tiny nub-pinched between his fingers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is so nice. It's like where Andy Hardy  would live. What's it called again?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kinship.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kinship. And what's here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Unless I miss my bet...my wife. James' heavy eyelids flutter with surprise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The one that left you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right. That one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GRADY RAPS on the front door, then cups his hands against the glass of the living room window, squints inside.  Nothing. As he turns away, GRADY sees James sitting on th hood of the Galaxie with the box of powdered donuts. He's sitting in the indentation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Someone jumped on your car with their butt ..-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How can you tell?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can see the outline of a butt. As GRADY nods, James holds out the donut box. JAMES LEER (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Want one. They're incredible. Incredible.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Smoke the rest of that joint, James, and you  can start on the box.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As GRADY steps onto the back porch, James follows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe she didn't come here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She came here. We'll just wait. In the  meantime, I need you to shimmy through. James stares at the "Doggy Door" cut into the back porch  door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Relax. Emily hasn't carried a house key since  she was twelve years old. And your hips are as  slim as hers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not that. It just reminded me of-- you  know-of what's in the car. In the trunk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a pang of guilt himself)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh. Right. Well, let's try not to think about  that. James takes another sad glance at the little door, then  drops onto ail fours.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GRADY leads James through the house. Everything about it  speaks of family. Even the furniture seems arranged so th people will gather together, light a fire, talk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It feels really... good. ..here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know. It's the house you want to wake up in  on Christmas morning. (moving off)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Make yourself at home. I'll be right back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grady, laboring badly on his ankle", enters and finds a  DUFFEL BAG open on the floor, its contents a tangle of  quickly-packed clothes. Everything else in the room feels of another time. PHOTOGRAPHS are everywhere, documenting PRETTY GIRL'S life, from first recital to cap and gown. One photograph lies face down. GRADY turns it over and  finds the pretty girl grown into a beautiful young woman, standing in a white gown next to a younger Grady--on thei wedding day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: James enters, FRENCH ROLL in hand, and sees a REMOTE  CONTROL atop the BAR. Taking it, he points it at the WIDE SCREEN TELEVISION imbedded in the opposite wall and,  seconds later, GEORGE SANDERS walks into his CLOSE-UP.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's no such thing as a good influence, Mr.  Gray. All influence is immoral...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grady, a PINK PRINCESS PHONE to his ear, lies on the bed  next to a huge TEDDY BEAR.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into phone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, I' m looking for the Chancellor... I  don't know. She should be in the main hall  ...Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: James runs through the channels, pauses on MARTIN MILNER  and GEORGE MAHARIS, riding in their curvy Corvette.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A Nelson Riddle's THEME FROM ROUTE 66 BOOMS from below,

dialogues.speaker: GRADY
dialogues.text: cups a hand over his ear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sara? Hi. It's Grady.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where are you, Grady? An elevator?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm in Kinship. Listen, Sara, there's some  things we need to talk about...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (evenly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're in Kinship?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. But that's not why I called...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With Emily?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? No'. There's no one here. I'm just  ...just....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just what? Doing a little dusting? As GRADY endeavors to respond, TWO YOUTHFUL VOICES,  CHEERFULLY SINGING, rise from below.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good Morning! Good Morning!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (yelling)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: James! For Christ sake, will you turn that  thing down!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: James? He's still with you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: James, in the midst of pouring himself a tumbler of  Bushmills, smiles as JUDY GARLAND and MICKEY ROONEY sing  their hearts out in Babes In Arms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We talked the whole night through!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GRADY shakes his head, carries the phone toward the  bedroom WINDOW.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, Sara. ..I'm not here. ..I'm not here to  . . . As GRADY watches, a late-model PONTIAC BONNEVIlLE turns  into the driveway below him. GRADY (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...reconcile with Emily.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you there to not reconcile with her? The Bonneville's trunk pops open, revealing THREE BAGS OF GROCERIES, and HANK and IRENE WINTERS, both in their 60's get out. An enormous NEWFOUNDLAND vaults from the backsea Sara, eating phone static this whole time, interprets  Grady's silence her own way. SARA'S VOICE (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goodbye, Grady.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. Sara, you don't understand...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Trust me, I understand. I just want to say  something to you, Grady.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (dreading it)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yea?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How you choose to live your own life is your  business. But you be careful with that boy,  Grady. With James. He belongs to somebody else. As the line goes dead, GRADY watches Hank and Irene  Winters disappear below him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: James--Irish whiskey in one hand, the pride of Humboldt  County in the other--watches with deep absorption as Judy and Mickey have a heartfelt conversation. Then, sensing  something ...he turns. Hank and Irene Winters, grocery bags in arm, stand  frozen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hullo. FOOTSTEPS are HEARD on the staircase and GRADY hobbies  into view. He tries a smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mom. Dad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hank Winters emerges from the bathroom with a roll of  tape, a bottle of alcohol, and some cotton wool.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, it's infected, I can tell you that. I'm  just going to clean it up a bit. It's up to you  to-find someone who knows what they're doing.  Here. Put your foot up. GRADY puts his foot up on Hank's lazy-Boy, then notices a BOOK lying face down on the seat. The AUTHOR on the back  cover looks as if he's trying very hard to look  consequential. To his surprise, GRADY realizes the author is himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So he's one of your students, this boy? GRADY glances into the living room, where James and Irene sit on a long couch together, sipping something hot. Jame is looking out the window, a curious expression on his  face. GRADY looks out his own window, sees the Newfoundla sniffing curiously at-the Galaxie's trunk. When he glance back into the living room, he and James make brief eye  contact, then blink, look away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. He's a good kid. Maybe a little messed  up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I'm sure with the proper guidance he'll  be fine. GRADY tries to read Hank's face---is he messing with  him?--but Hank gives nothing away. GRADY nods to the book

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What made you pull out that old thing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shrugging)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was thinking of you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's no Arsonist's Daughter, but I guess you  know that. It's a young man's book. It got me  remembering how it felt to be young.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe I should read it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I don't think there's any danger of you  aging prematurely, Grady. GRADY doesn't have to read Hank's face this time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where's Emily, Hank?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I 'don't know if she'd want me  to tell you  that, Grady.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not going to stalk her. Hank. I just.  ..want to know where I stand. Hank looks up, incredulous.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where you stand?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (embarrassed)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: l-just want to say I'm sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's in Philadelphia seeing Linda Aahby. The  neurologist.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Neurologist? Why? What's wrong?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (frowning)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing's wrong. They went to Wellesley  together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sheepishly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh. Right. Linda ...I haven't been doing a lot  of sleeping lately. My editor's in town and I  have the book to finish and--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah, right. The book. GRADY starts to continue, then stops, cowed by something  in Hank's tone, something dismissive. Instead, he looks  away, toward the living room, and catches sight of James  again, sitting alone now with his big cup of cocoa.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen, Hank, I'm sorry about ail this. I  didn't come here to upset you and Irene. I want  you to know that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why did you come here, Grady? GRADY gestures vaguely.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I -just wanted to see her, I guess-- Emily.  And to see you too-you and Irene. And to let  everyone know that, even though it may be  difficult to comprehend now, this-everything  that's happening-it's not forever. It doesn't  mean "Goodbye."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Give me a break, Grady. Hank snaps off the tape, slaps Grady's ankle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're done.

dialogues.speaker: DUSK 71
dialogues.text: GRADY glowers darkly at the road, then puts his hand up  against the HEATING VENT which, apparently, is not puttin out any heat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm having a really good time, Professor  Tripp. GRADY glances over, sees James burrowing into the Ziploc.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm really happy for you, James. But do me a  favor, will you? Lay off my dope. That stuff's  not for amateurs. James looks at Ziploc as GRADY fiddles with the heat  LEVER.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just wanted a little sip.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (squinting at him)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just wanted a little sip? Tell me, James,  exactly what point was it that you turned into  Serpent Boy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Probably about the time you gave me the  codeine pills last night. GRADY stops with the heater, glances over at James, whose face bears not the slightest trace of irony.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus...  (thinking, then. . . )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, James, you appear to possess-like many  an aspiring writer before you, by the way-a  rather ardent affinity for the stuff of which  dreams are made. However, I 'think it's best  if, for the moment at least (taking the Ziploc) ...we abstain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're mad at me, aren't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're mad because I shot your girlfriend's  dog.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It wasn't her dog. It's her husband's-- (stopping)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who said anything about girlfriend? James eyes shift slowly, as if to 'say: Who are you  kidding?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, James, I wish you hadn't shot my  girlfriend's dog. Even though Poe and I weren't  exactly what you'd call simpatico, that's no  reason for him to take two in the chest. Still,  the fact remains that I'm the one who took you  up into the Chancellor's bedroom. I'm the one  who has to take the blame. I- don't know what  the hell I was thinking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure you do. You were thinking: 'That's no cap  gun in that kid's overcoat.' You were thinking  'I can't let that kid get on. the bus alone-he  might never get on the bus again.' You were  thinking: 'I've got to find a way to distract  this kid. ' So you did. It was--in its way--a  noble act.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks for the halo, James, but I've . never  done that much thinking ahead in my" life-ever. James looks -out the window, pondering this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, why did you take me up there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (feeling for the heat again)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I -don' t know, James . I don' t know why I do  half the things I do. Who does? (looking over)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why do you wear that coat? James looks down, a little defensive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's warm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: James, fall semester, first day of class, it  was 95 degrees and you were wearing the coat. James just blinks, no ready answer-available.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's why they all give you such a hard time  in workshop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because of my coat?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because you act like a goddamn spook all the  time. Not to mention the fact that every last  one of them is jealous of you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smirking)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jealous? Of me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not you. Your talent. James' face hardens. He looks away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're lying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The hell I am.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes you are. My stuff stinks. I know it. You  said so yourself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I never said that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes you did. Last night. To your friend  Crabtree. "Is he any good?" he said. And you  said: "Not yet he isn't." I heard you myself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't mean it that way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's okay, Professor Tripp. Carrie, Howard,  the others--they 're right. My stories are  annoying. They go on and on and on, and the  longer they go on the more annoying they  become, until finally you just want to grab  something heavy and--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shut up, James. You're annoying. Carrie and  Howard don't know what the fuck they're talking  about, okay? The entire class combined- including the lovely Hannah Green-has about one  tenth of one percent the talent you have, okay? James stares blankly at Grady, then turns his face to the window. He ponders Grady's words, the praise inherent in  them. A hint of pleasure glints in his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But, last night...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who cares what-. I said last night, James I I  was drunk, I was stoned. I'd been bitten by a  dog. My wife had left me. How 'bout cutting me  some slack?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quietly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And don't be so goddamn sensitive. Who cares  what anybody thinks anyway? You want to .be a  good writer? You want to be-a great writer?  Then stop giving a damn what other people  think. Most of them haven't thought in .years. James turns, studies Grady's face as it flickers in the  first headlights of the evening.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me spell it .out for you, James. Books  don't mean anything. Not to anybody. Not  anymore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arsonist's Daughter meant something. GRADY smiles contemptuously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean it. It means something to me. It's one  of the reasons I came to school here. To be in  your class. To be taught by you. (quietly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's one of the reasons I wanted to become a  writer. GRADY stares ahead, watching the darkness tumble away  before the wide sweep of the Galaxie's headlights.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, for that, if nothing else, James, I'm  sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GRADY rolls into a space near the coffee shop and James  slides out. GRADY stays put, hands still on the wheel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You coming?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In a minute. Get us a table. James nods, pushes past the glass doors into the coffee  shop, and a big REDHEAD in a waitress cap leads him to a  table with a view of the highway. GRADY watches James-- stick figure in black brogues--slide into the booth and open his big, laminated menu. Finally, as if concluding some internal debate, GRADY  kicks open his door, steps out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GRADY rests his forehead against the PAYPHONE as he  speaks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: C-a-r-v-e-I. That's right, Carvel. Yes, I'm  sure. It's outside Scranton. GRADY straightens up, takes a peek at James, sitting by  himself on the far side of the coffee shop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have no listing. Okay, well, lady-- at  this very moment, as we speak, I'm looking of a  resident of Carvel, Pennsylvania. I think he'd  be pretty interested to learn that the good  people of Bell Atlantic have misplaced his  entire hometown. It's not like I'm making this  up as I go along-- GRADY stops, his own words ringing in his head. GRADY (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Never mind. My mistake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GRADY upends James' knapsack, sifts through: An  AUTOGRAPHED POSTCARD of FRANCES FARMER. A wrinkled box of CHICLETS. Nothing. Then he notices ERROL FLYNN'S eyebrows peeking at him from the knapsack's side pouch. He takes the book, opens it. Bingo. A library notice:  James Seiwyn Leer is three weeks overdue. Under ADDRESS i says only: "On File." But if one was to dial the PHONE  NUMBER, odds are it won't be the night janitor at the  Greyhound depot who picks up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The remains of a FRIED CLAM SANDWICH sit before James as  he turns his attention to a GIANT PIECE OF LEMON MERINGUE PIE. GRADY sips only coffee, stealing glances at the cars that whip by on the highway beyond the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Want a bite?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's why you're having them. Your spells.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Spells? Jesus, James, you make it sound like  we're in a Tennessee Williams play. I don't  have spells.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What would you call them then?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. ...'Episodes.' James shrugs, spears a fluffy chunk of pie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's because you don't eat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I eat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When nobody's looking. GRADY watches a pair of headlights approach...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (mouth full, garbled)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just worry about you, that's all. ...then pass. James' words finally register. GRADY looks  at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You just worry about yourself, James. Okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. Just then, a long, pale WAND of LIGHT splinters against  the coffee shop windows and a CAR sweeps into the parking lot. GRADY follows it with his eyes, rises. JAMES LEER (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where you going?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nowhere. You just sit here and... eat. GRADY moves off, then stops, looking back at James and  his giant piece of pie, still troubled by his words.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As GRADY limps out of the coffee shop, he finds an OLDER  MAN in a TUXEDO standing in the open door of a gleaming  BLACK MERCEDES. Beyond him, in the front passenger seat, WOMAN in MINK examines her eye shadow in the tiny mirror the sun visor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (eyeing GRADY dubiously)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Professor Tripp?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grady.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fred Leer. This is my wife Amanda.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (re: their clothes)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Looks like I've dashed a-wonderful evening.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hardly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We were on our way to a benefit. But, as luck  would have it, the club was on the way, so...  (snapping shut the visor)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We were able to put in an appearance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Otherwise we would've been here earlier.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah. Well, that's ail right. James and I 'had a  little dinner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, certainly we'll reimburse you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's not necessary. I just felt. ..it might  be good for James to be with his family this  weekend.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, of course, we can understand that. GRADY considers the two glittering ghosts before him.  They seem to be waiting. Just waiting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well. Let me go get him. GRADY turns for the coffee shop, then stops, looks back. GRADY (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I "hope you won't consider this forward of me,  Amanda, but I wonder if I might ask. ..did you  ever attend Catholic school? Amanda Leer's eyes narrow ever-so-slightly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: James is glowering at the parking lot as GRADY returns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not going with them..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: James. Listen. Things-things are a little  weird with me right now and I-- well--I have  enough blame to shoulder these days without  having to take the blame if something bad  happened to you. And if you hang around me long  enough, something bad is going to happen, trust  me. That's why I need you to go home.  Understand?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not going, with them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: James, like it or not, they're your parents.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Parents? They're not my parents. They're my  grandparents. My parents are dead. GRADY stares at-James wearily.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I swear. My father had his own airplane he  used to fly up to Quebec. One Christmas, he and  my mom were flying up to our house in the  Laurentians when the plane went down. It was in  the newspaper. GRADY doesn't flinch, unpersuaded.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I 'swear. My father was a senior vice  president at Dravo. My mother was a socialite.  Her maiden name was Guggenheim. GRADY starts to protest, then pauses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I remember that. Five or six years ago.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Six. Their plane went down right outside  Scranton.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sardonically)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Near Carvel?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry about all that. I just-I don't like  to talk about my family. They treat me like a  freak.  (nodding towards Amanda)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She makes me sleep in. the basement of my own house. It's mine. My parents left it to me. GRADY glances toward the parking lot, studies the   contours of Fred Leer's face. Frowns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: James, come on. That man is obviously your  father. You look just like him. James looks down at the table, takes a deep breath, and  speaks in a voice heavy with implication.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's a reason for that. Grady's addled brain grapples with this dark little  riddle, finally deciphers what James is suggesting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get out of here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's why she hates me. That's why she makes  me sleep in the basement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the crawl space, with the rats and the  casks of Amontillado. Come on. Up. As GRADY lifts him from the booth, James attempts a  plaintive tone, but his heart's not in it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I swear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Fred Leer SLAMS the back door of the Mercedes, GRADY  waves vaguely, peers into the darkness of the back seat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you. Professor Tripp.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take care of him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, don't worry. We'll take care of him. You  can be sure of that. Fred Leer hits the gas and swings the Mercedes around in  a tight little arc, feathering Grady's pants--from the kn down--with a pudding of ICE and MUD. GRADY glances down a his spattered self, then notices, sitting on the front  passenger seat, James' knapsack. GRADY grabs it, turns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey!

dialogues.speaker: REAR WINDOW
dialogues.text: as the Mercedes begins to pull away and James turns,  elbows on the back dash, his pale face slack. Spying Grad he raises one limp hand, and then-as if it were held by a string-lets it drop. GRADY (cont'd)  (softly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GRADY sits in-the GREEN GLOW of .the radio dial, smoking  a joint. He glances at the knapsack, sees James'

dialogues.speaker: MANUSCRIPT
dialogues.text: The Love Parade He reaches in, takes the manuscript and, in the light  that rains from the PARKING LAMP overhead, begins to read

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grady's HOUSE looks like a three-dollar whore on a block  full of nuns. MUSIC BLARES, LIGHT BLAZES from every windo and there are so many CARS GRADY is forced to leave the  Galaxie in the middle of the street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (knowingly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crabtree.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Times Square before the ball drops. GRADY enters, scans  the room, then shoulders his way to the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hannah Green sits on the sofa, twisting a long strand of  hair around her finger as she reads a THICK MANUSCRIPT.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (entering)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grady! She slaps the page she is reading back onto the stack at  her thigh. GRADY stares. The manuscript. It's his.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (embarrassed)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know I shouldn't have, but there it was,  just sort of lying out, and I couldn't resist  and-and--I suck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, it's okay. I just can't believe I left it  out in the open like that. CRABTREE hasn't been  in here, has he? Poking around?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know--maybe- I don't think so. Grady's  mind races with unfortunate possibilities, but  only briefly: his immediate thoughts are elsewhere.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen, Hannah. You don't remember where that  aunt worked, do you? James' aunt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He shot the Chancellor's dog, didn't he? The  blind one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Actually, He's not the Chancellor' s--What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At first the police thought he just ran away,  but this afternoon Dr. Gaskell found some blood  spots on the carpet -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CRABTREE said it sounded like something James  would be messed up in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crabtree? He doesn't even know James.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who does? Just then, Crabtree's VOICE bellows in the hallway  outside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Trip?! Where are you' GRADY looks anxiously toward the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The aunt, Hannah. Where did you take James  that day?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I told you, Sewickly Heights.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But where? I need the street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know, Grady. I just dropped him on a  corner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Trip?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shit. As GRADY starts to turn away, Hannah hooks her finger  inside his belt buckle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No! Don't go. I've been waiting ail night for  you. GRADY looks at Hannah's hand, where it rests. He looks  terrified.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen, Hannah, I'm flattered, really, but  right now I--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (bursting in)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tripp, where the hell. . . CRABTREE stops, takes in the tableau before him. CRABTREE (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I'm sorry. Am I interrupting a. student- teacher conference? GRADY delicately removes Hannah's hand from his buckle,  points at Crabtree.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You stay there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? Ohhhh. Is that... it? CRABTREE cocks his head toward the reams of paper stacked on Grady's desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Honestly, Tripp. Do you actually think I would  sneak in here and read your book without asking  you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gee, I don't know. Crabs. I don't seem to  remember you actually asking me if you could  invite 200 people over to trash my living room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sometimes we have to improvise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (ignoring him)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Think, Hannah. Does James have any friends. I  mean, besides you and. ..me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: James? My James? What's happened?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing, he's just been sort of, I don't  know.. .kidnapped.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kidnapped? By who?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His parents.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good God. Let's go rescue him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good idea. Crabs. Only one problem. I don't  know where they live.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah. Wait a minute. The university must know  where he lives.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a little late to call Admissions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is it a little late to call the Chancellor?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe ...I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two-sixty-two Baxter Drive. GRADY and CRABTREE turn, see Hannah sitting on the corner of Grady's desk with the WHITE PAGES open on her lap. HANNAH GREEN (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're in the book.

dialogues.speaker: TEN MINUTES LATER
dialogues.text: CRABTREE snaps James' manuscript closed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know--based on what I've read-- this is a  very exciting piece of material, this Big  Parade.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Love. It's Love facade--and what do you mean  'based on what you've read'? You skimmed two  chapters at 80 miles an hour while gargling  methamphetamines.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've been doing this a long time, Tripp. I  feel this kid in my bones.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Only in your bones? GRADY smirks, glances at Crabtree, but gets a surprise;  CRABTREE offers no snappy come-back, no antic wordplay. H just stares out the window, his voice distant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. I think I might be right. I've felt it  before... As Crabtree's voice trails off, GRADY studies him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How bad is it for you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bad enough. And God knows I don't exactly fit  the new corporate profile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Which is?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Competence. GRADY and CRABTREE look at each other a moment, then  CRABTREE smiles, gives a little shrug, and picks up James knapsack, rummaging through the contents. CRABTREE (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So tell me about you and the Chancellor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's to tell?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Plenty, I'm sure. But, for what it's worth... CRABTREE fishes out the biography of Erroll Flynn, gives  it a look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...I like her. GRADY peers at the stars, his voice barely audible.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Me too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The battered Galaxie floats up a narrow road, gliding  through a canyon of mansion walls and the occasional  winding drive. Up ahead a stone post marker with the  numerals "262." GRADY kills the headlights.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grady--limping like an aging prizefighter--leads CRABTREE up a steep incline toward an enormous three-story house.  The Leer's Mercedes gleams in the shadows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus. There must be two dozen windows on .  that thing. How are we-supposed to find his?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I told you. They keep him chained in the  basement. Come on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LIGHT GLOWS from a low BASEMENT WINDOW. From one side, a  WOMAN is HEARD SINGING. GRADY and CRABTREE pause, listen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why should I care though he gave me the air?  Why should I cry, heave a sigh, and wonder why?  And wonder why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doris Day. CRABTREE and GRADY look at each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: James Leer. GRADY moves to the window and RAPS on the glass. A moment later, James peeks out. Seeing Grady, his face brightens  briefly, unguarded, then quickly resumes its usual Leeria aspect. He motions with his hand, as if to say, "That way

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The DOOR swings open to reveal James Leer, decked out in  a pair of RED, INK-STAINED PAJAMAS sagging badly in the  seat. He looks like one of Santa's elves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey. What are you guys doing here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're springing you. Leer. Get some pants on. As they step inside, GRADY gives James' PJs the once- over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't believe you made fun of my robe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Electric CANDELABRAS light a large converted cellar whose walls are crowded with MOVIE POSTERS and LOBBY CARDS. The are STACKS of what look suspiciously like LIBRARY BOOKS a an enormous BAROQUE BED, complete with CANOPY.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I like what you've done with it. When's  Captain Nemo moving in?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The candelabras were my Gran's.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, Christ, don't start on ol' Gran or we'll  leave you here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, I heard all about it--the parents, the  grandparents, the China town thing-- and I  believe you, okay? That's why we're here. Now  go get dressed. James scoops up the shirt GRADY lent him. this morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I--I mean--do you mind--if I wear this  again. Professor Tripp?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah, wear whatever you want. James flinches, stung, then disappears into a bathroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So modest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So sensitive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nosing around the room)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, come on, Tripp. Cut the kid some slack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's just ail that crap he spins out. Just  once I'd like to know if the little bastard is  telling the truth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The-truth. I know that's always been real  important to you. Key, check this out... CRABTREE leans over an old ROYAL TYPEWRITER, reads from  the freshly-typed PAGE curling from the carriage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Finally, the door opened. It-was a shock to:  see him, shuffling into the room like an aging  prizefighter. Limping. Beaten.' (with an amused smile)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sound like anyone we know? (resuming)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But it was later, when the great man squinted  into the bitter glow or twilight... (frowning)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bitter glow of twilight? This kid definitely  needs an editor. (resuming)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...and muttered simply, "It means nothing. All of it.  Nothing," that the true shock came. It was then that the  boy understood that his hero's true injuries lay hidden i a darker place. His heart...' CRABTREE stops abruptly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes? 'His heart...' CRABTREE hesitates, then... reads on:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'His heart, once capable of inspiring others  so completely, could no longer inspire so much  as itself. It beat now only out of habit. It  beat now only because it could. ' GRADY nods, his face unreadable, then James returns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm ready... James stops, sees the two men looking at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You all right, Professor Tripp?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's great. Come on, let's blow before ol'  Gran decides to boil your bones for breakfast.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, well, that's just it. She's been coming  down here, every half hour or so, to, sort of,  check on me. If I'm not here, she might ...call  the police or.. .something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hhhuh. So we decoy her. Stick a couple pillows  and one of your teddy bears under the spread  and she won't know the difference.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (brightening)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. Like in Against All Flags. Only they use  a couple big hams.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. CRABTREE and James turn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've got something better than a teddy bear. CUT TO: POE -- as he's lowered delicately onto James'  bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GRADY strategically arranges the coverlet, gently  adjusting Poe's head so only a TUFT of FUR shows. He step back, joining CRABTREE and James for an assessment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sweet dreams, Jimmy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The lights are still blazing, the front door is wide  open, but not a soul remains.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A quiet disaster, the only sound an LP playing meekly on  the STEREO. James passes through first, ignoring the  TORTILLA CHIPS POPPING under his shoes, then CRABTREE and GRADY appear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Things must've picked up after we left. CRABTREE pats Grady's cheek, heads upstairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crabtree's door is closing as GRADY hobbles into view.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crabtree.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sticking his head out)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ye-es? GRADY looks down, sees James Leer's black brogues sitting on the floor outside Crabtree's door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing. The door closes, the LATCH CLICKS, and GRADY is left  alone, the bossa nova floating softly in the air.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hannah Green lies tangled in the sheets, surrounded by  little colonies of Grady's manuscript. GRADY studies her, then detects something on the floor. The red boots. Delicately, he lifts the sheet. Hannah Green's feet--  finally revealed in ail their naked glory--prove to be  thick, wide, and ordinary. GRADY sighs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The TV is on. GRADY steps to the doorway, pauses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey. A HEAD cranes over the sofa. It's the Goatee Kid from  Thaw Hail.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How are you--is it Joe?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeff. Sorry. I didn't even know this was your  house until about an hour ago.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't sweat it. Well. 'Night, Jeff.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, Professor Tripp? You know, last semester,  what I said that time in office hours-I hope  there's no hard feelings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean, I was breaking up with this girl at  the time and my car was ail fucked up and-- well--I was pretty bent in general.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's cool, Jeff. Really.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just want you to know that's why I dropped  your class and said all that shit about the  university stealing my money and you being a  pseudo-Faulknerian nobody.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GRADY sits quietly on the porch steps, a joint burning in his fingers. To his left, perched atop a Haagen-Dazs  container, is a TELEPHONE. As he pulls it into his lap, a LAMP in the living room pirouettes clumsily, spins free o the cord, and SHATTERS on the floor. GRADY blinks, looks away, and DIALS, just as. ..the  CLATTERING COUGH of an ENGINE is HEARD and a VAN appears. Stenciled on its side panel is: Kravnik's Sporting Goods The van slows, almost coasting, then abruptly bursts past Grady's house and disappears around the corner. GRADY  frowns, then realizes a MAN'S VOICE is coming from the  RECEIVER in his lap.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello? Hello...? The VOICE is groggy. It is Walter Gaskell's voice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes? GRADY says nothing, as if wondering what he's doing. WALTER'S VOICE (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who's this ?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's Grady, Walter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grady?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GRADY Tripp. English Department.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know it's you, Grady, I just... Christ,  Grady, do you know what time it -is?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking at his watch)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have ...eight-fifteen. That's not right, is  it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's three-thirty, Grady.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is important.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is it, Grady?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm in love with your wife.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sara. I'm in love with her. Silence. Then Walter's VOICE returns: even,  administrative.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you drinking. Professor Tripp? Right now. GRADY sips on his roach, responds in a pinched voice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nevertheless, I'd like to see you in my office  Monday morning. As the line goes dead, GRADY stares at the phone,  wondering if he has, in fact, just done what he thinks he just done.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A CAR rattles down the street, NEWSPAPERS pinwheeling  from-the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A heavy THHNK hits the driveway outside and GRADY blinks. Sitting in his pink robe, bleary-eyed, he reconsiders the piece of paper curling from his typewriter. GRADY'S POV - of THE PAGE It's obvious he's been sitting like this for some time.  Just then, the DISTINCTIVE PURR of an ENGINE is HEARD.  GRADY peers through the window, watches a CAB. glide to t curb below. A Citroen DS23. Sara.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GRADY steps onto the porch, unintentionally punting a  BOTTLE of Iron City Beer onto the front lawn..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sara.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I tried to call, but apparently there's  something wrong... Sara leans down, replaces the uncradled phone. SARA (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...with your phone. Unfortunately, mine was  ringing loud and clear this morning. GRADY doesn't know what this means, but he's pretty sure  it's not good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It seems one of our students is - missing and  his parents found a dead dog in his bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (slumping to the porch)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, Sara. I've been trying to tell you.  It's all my- Sara raises her hand, silencing him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not very happy with you right now, Grady.  But more importantly, Walter's not very happy  and he's gotten the police involved. They seem  to think James Leer is somehow responsible for  all of this. You wouldn't happen to know where  James is, would you, Grady?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And the jacket?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Over there. In the backseat of the... Grady's hand hangs in mid-air, gesturing pointlessly to  the driveway, where the only thing that exists is an oil  stain roughly the shape of North Dakota. GRADY (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Someone stole my car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grady.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Honestly. Someone stole my car. I parked it  right there last night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you sure you parked it there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course, I'm sure.  Ah, Christ, the puberty  police are back. Sara turns, sees Officer Pupcik cruising to the curb.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll deal with this. You dig up James.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CRABTREE sits in bed, flipping through the pages of The  Love Parade while stroking a tiny TUFT of HAIR that is th . sole visible part of .James Leer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (swinging in)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is he awake?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm afraid he's pretty worn out, poor kid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nevertheless. There's a police officer  standing on the porch and I don't think he's  going away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (from under the covers)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That same guy? CRABTREE peels back the blankets and James Leer opens one eye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You snore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So I hear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (studying Grady)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No offense, Professor Tripp, but you look  sorta crappy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's right, you look horrible.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, Frankie and Annette. James swings his pale little legs to the floor and walks  bare assed across the room to retrieve his BVDs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's the Chancellor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah, right. Well, I gave you my opinion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And we both thank you for that, but we're...  we're... fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm fine, right. Fit as a fucking fiddle. GRADY squints at James as he pulls on his pants.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shut up, James.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So what's the problem?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a tad tense)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is no problem. Did I say there was a  problem? As James' head pops through Grady's fully-buttoned  flannel, he and CRABTREE exchange a knowing glance, at once referring to and  excluding Grady.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How's it coming back there, Professor Tripp?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who's that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who do you think it is?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Chancellor's here? Now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Evidently.  (calling)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coming!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Does she mean--does she know about ...her dog?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's Walter's dog and yes, she does. Know. But  let's spare her the details. Come on, your  shoes are in the hail.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: James. This book of yours. It's not bad. Not  bad at all. James stops, considers this piece of news with a look of  deep seriousness, then nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're welcome. As James shuffles off into the hail, CRABTREE looks at  Grady, his eyes dancing with excitement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want to publish this.  I've got to.  I think  they'll let me.  With a little editorial  guidance it could be brilliant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Great. Between you and Officer Pupcik out  there he can be the next Jean Genet. It's been  awhile since somebody wrote a good book in  jail.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sara and GRADY stand by as Pete Pupcik deposits James in  the back of the squad car, SLAMS the door.

dialogues.speaker: PUPCIK
dialogues.text: As I told the Chancellor, Professor, I'm. just going to  run James here over to the university. It'll be up to Dr. Gaskell where we go from there. GRADY nods, leans in the window to James.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't worry, James, I'll figure something out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not worried. You're not worried, are you.  Professor Tripp?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm a little worried, James.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't be. I don't care if they expel me. I  probably should be expelled.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, let's see if we can keep that from  happening. James nods and GRADY starts to step back from the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Professor Tripp...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, James.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Even if I end up going to jail.... James smiles his crooked grin. JAMES LEER (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're still the best teacher I ever had. On this,  Pete Pupcik pulls away, leaving GRADY standing  on the curb, watching the back of James' head, framed in  the rear  window of the police car, growing smaller.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is not what the university has in mind  when it promises a liberal education, Grady.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would Walter really press charges?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's within the realm. He takes his souvenirs  pretty seriously. And he was just a wee bit  prickly this morning. Grady, detecting something in Sara's tone, turns, watches her take a drag on her cigarette. SARA (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You didn't happen to call the house last  night, did you, Grady?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think I might have.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And what do you think you might have said?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think I might've said I was in love with  you. Sara's face remains .unchanged. GRADY (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He told you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He told me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And what did you say?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I said it didn't sound like you.  Sara tosses her cigarette in .the gutter, gets into her  car, and dives away.  GRADY looks after her sadly, then  turns, sees CRABTREE standing on the porch wearing a shir which claims "Ativan Chases the Clouds Away."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So- what do we do now? ,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Find the jacket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh' huh. Exactly how do we do that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: First I see if Hannah will let me borrow her  car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It seems to me that girl would let you borrow  her pancreas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hannah, wrapped loosely in cotton sheets, SMILES as she  listens to the Goatee Kid, who sits cross-legged at the  foot of-her bed, fully clothed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm telling you, the tango is ail about latent  homosexual love. Look at the way they dance-- it's sodomy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (laughing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stop it. Hannah looks up, sees GRADY in the doorway and blushes.  She pulls the sheet up, gives an oddly formal wave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grady. Hi. What's up? Jeff eases off the bed, past GRADY uneasily.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll be ...somewhere else.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Jeff. If you're really interested in  discussing that business with the tango, try  the guy at the end of the hall. Jeff nods--puzzled--then goes. GRADY smirks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He cribbed that from Borges.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It beats 'What's your major?' GRADY nods, detecting a new aloofness in her voice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right. Anyway, I was wondering if I could  borrow your car. Mine's sort of out of  commission.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure. The keys are on the dresser next to.  ..to your book. The hitch in Hannah's voice hangs in the room like a  cloud.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I uh, I didn't finish, I ...fell asleep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That good, hub?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, it's not that, it's... Hannah glances at the huge stack of paper sitting on her  dresser, then, hesitantly, looks back to Grady.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's just that, you know, I was thinking about  how, in class, you're always telling us '-that  writers make choices--at least the good ones.  And, don't get me wrong. I'm not saying the  book isn't really great-I mean, really great- but at times it's, well, very detailed, you  know, with the genealogies of everyone's horses  and ail the dental records and so on-and I  don't know, maybe I'm wrong, but it sort of  reads, in places, like, well, actually, like...  (with trepidation)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...you didn't make any choices at all. And I was  wondering if it might not be different if, maybe, when yo wrote, you weren't always ...under the influence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (stung)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hh huh. Well, thanks for the thought, but, as  shocking as this may sound, I'm not the first  writer to sip a little weed. And furthermore,  it might interest you to know that one book I  wrote, as you say, 'under the influence, '  happened to win a little something called the  PEN award which, by the way, I accepted 'under  the influence. ' Hannah nods, averts her eyes, and immediately GRADY feels ridiculous. He starts to say something, but instead gathe his manuscript and exits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crabtree, dressed now, studies the freight 'in Grady's  arms as he reaches the bottom of the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Want some help with that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (passing by)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't touch it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CRABTREE sucks on a Kool, driving Hannah's rattling  Renault too fast, shifting gears apparently at random.  GRADY rides shotgun, still wearing the robe over his  clothes, the Wonder Boys manuscript sitting like a  watermelon on his lap-looking, all in all, fairly patheti

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me get this straight. Jerry Nathan owes  you money. So, as collateral, he gives you his  car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Only now I'm starting to think the car wasn't  exactly Jerry's to give.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So whose car is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My guess-Vernon Hardapple.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The hood jumper?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He said a few things that lead me to believe  the car's his.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Such as.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'That's my car, motherfucker.'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hh hub. So. We find Vernon, we find the car.  We find the car...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...we find the jacket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's only one problem, Tripp. We don't know  his real name. We just made it up. In fact, we  made the whole guy up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No wonder he screwed us over.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: BILL MAZEROSKI legendary Pittsburgh Pirate second  baseman, large as a Macy's Day float, his weathered image scaling three floors on the BRICK face of a RIVERFRONT  STOREFRONT.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CRABTREE takes a corner recklessly, immediately slows,  and blinks in amazement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Christ, Tripp. How did you know?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Call it a hunch. Parked in front of KRAVNIK'S SPORTING GOODS is the white  van. A few feet behind, the battered Galaxie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd call it genius. GRADY steps out, strips off the robe, and drops the lumpy leviathan that is his manuscript on the front seat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's good to know I'm still talented at  something. Keep the motor running.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GRADY peers into the backseat, squinting against the WIND that swirls around him. Errol Flynn's face leers back at  him. But no jacket. GRADY slides in, pops the glove box,  and frowns at the ZIPLOC of Humboldt County. He pockets i anyway, then spies something else. James Leer's little PEARL-HANDLED PISTOL. GRADY takes it, rotates it-in his palm. SUNLIGHT GLINTS  off the chrome barrel and everything slowly turns to a  SWEET, SOFT BLUR...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CRABTREE stomps on his Kool. GRADY looks very much like a man who has pulled off the road to take a nap.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the hell...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As GRADY lolls behind the steering wheel, a CLOUD  appears, hovering, then slowly mutates, and GRADY realize it's not a cloud at all, it's MARILYN MONROE standing by the side mirror, wearing a  bright pink dress under her wedding jacket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know you. . . Marilyn's face swims before Grady's eyes, but there's  something wrong with it. This girl's eyes are brown and  besides, she's ...fat. MARILYN (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
