dialogues.text: Double Dickel on the rocks. The last of the fairy dust evaporates and GRADY finds-  standing before him in a pink jersey dress and Marilyn  Monroe's wedding jacket--0ola, the pregnant waitress from the Hi-Hat Club.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oola.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I never forget a drink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I never forget an Oola. Suddenly, there is a HEAVY CLICK.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forget me? GRADY starts to turn, but his head won't  move: largely  because the BARREL of a GERMAN NINE is pressed to his  temple. Grady's eyes slide.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vernon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Oola)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Move away, cupcake.  He's got a gun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who's got a gun?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've got a gun, motherfucker. Drop it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Relax, Vernon...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why's he calling you Vernon?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why's he sitting in my car? He's crazy, that's  why. He probably calls everybody Vernon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not true. You're the only Vernon I know.  Actually, I'm wrong. I once knew a Vernon  Peabody at Penguin U.K.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shut up.  (to Oola)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cupcake. Please. Inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You' re not going to shoot him, are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm going to shoot him. If he doesn't put that  gun down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's just a souvenir. They don't even make the  caps anymore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bullshit. I know a gun when I see one. And  that's a gun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, really.... GRADY lifts his arm, points the little pearl-handled  pistol to the DARK CLOUDS overhead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CRABTREE jumps as the tiny pistol at the end of Grady's  arm FLASHES, makes a FEEBLE POP in the wind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Holy shit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vernon stands half-hunched, stunned.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you crazy! The gunshot seems to have cleared Grady's head. He stares at the gun, watches Vernon wrest it from his hand. VERNON (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get out! What's the matter with you? Can't you  see the condition my girl's in? As GRADY gets out of the car, Vernon places his hand on  Oola's tummy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You all right, cupcake?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who's Vernon? A rude SQUEAL breaks the silence--rubber scratching  asphalt--and Grady, Oola, and Vernon turn to see Hannah  Green's rattling Renault lurching awkwardly toward them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the...? Gears GRINDING, tires smoking, CRABTREE fish-tails  wildly, then kicks open the passenger door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tripp! Run! GRADY doesn't move an inch, watching in mute amazement as CRABTREE whistles by, proceeds halfway down the block, th turns back for another pass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who the hell is that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A Manhattan book editor murdering a Mormon  girl's clutch. The car bucks crazily, picks up speed, and Crabtree--  swiping aside a flutter of MANUSCRIPT PAGES that have tak flight inside the car--begins to veer right toward Grady, Vernon, and Oola.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Woah. Vernon steps into the street, levels the German Nine. VERNON (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pull off, you crazy motherfucker! Frantic, GRADY steps between Vernon, the German Nine, and the oncoming Crabtree.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No! Don't shoot! He's just a lousy driver. CRABTREE fans the wheel wildly, goes into a slide and the passenger door snaps wide, releasing what looks to be a  FLOCK OF WHITE DOVES into the wind-whipped sky. Only, these ain't birds.  В• - ^

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh... my... God!  These are PAGES. Seven years of-pages. CRABTREE goes into another slide, one-hops the curb, and  smashes flat into the weathered GLOVE of BILL MAZEROSKI  painted on the front wail of KRAVNIK'S SPORTING GOODS. As Hannah Green's RADIATOR EXPLODES, CRABTREE steps free  of the car and looks skyward. It's a ticker-tape parade a the way down the street, ending in the frigid waters of t Ohio River.  GRADY (cont'd) (to Vernon)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I take it back.  Shoot him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vernon drives, Oola at his side. In-the back, CRABTREE  puffs philosophically on a Kool while GRADY sits grimly  with the sad remains of his manuscript: SEVEN RUMPLED  PAGES, one of which bears the watermark of a shoe print.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Naturally you have copies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have an alternate version of the first  chapter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll be all right then.  Look at Carlyle,  when he lost his luggage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That was MacCaulay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Or Hemingway, when Hadley lost all those  stories.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He was never able to reproduce them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bad examples. Look, Tripp, I don't want to  depreciate the loss here, but perhaps--in a  sense- this-- (nodding to the pages)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: is for the best. Grady's eyes shift, study Crabtree.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kind of a sign, you're saying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In a sense.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think so. In my experience, signs are  usually a lot more subtle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me get this straight. All that paper that  went into the river. That was the only copy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Fraid so.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (glowering at Crabtree)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you're saying it's some kind of sign? What  the fuck's the matter with you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm just saying that sometimes,  subconsciously, a person will put themselves in  a situation-perhaps even create that situation- in order to have an arena in which to work out an unresolved issue. It's a covert way, if you  will, of addressing a problem. Vernon stares at CRABTREE as if he's from another planet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll tell you the problem. You behind the  wheel. There's your fucking problem.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's pretty simplistic, don't you think?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, pal, you don't start doing crazy eights  in the middle of the street none of this  happens.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me. Did you, or did you not, have a gun  to his head?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He was trying to steal my car!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ail right, all right It's done. There's no  need to talk about it. It's done. They ride in silence for a moment, then Oola turns,  glances at GRADY and his little sheaf of pages.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So what was it about?  (as GRADY looks up)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your book.  What was the story? GRADY stares into Oola's sweet, brown eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know... Oola's brow wrinkles. CRABTREE glances at his old friend, genuine compassion in his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What he means is, it's difficult to distill  the essence of a book sometimes. It-lives in  the mind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, but you gotta know what it's about,  right? I mean, if you didn't know what it was  about, why were you writing it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I couldn't stop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grady, James Leer's hollow knapsack in hand, stands with  CRABTREE at the campus entrance as Vernon and Oola prepar to leave in the Galaxie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Vernon. Can I ask you a question?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shoot. GRADY glances at little round Oola.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Boy or girl?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As long as it looks like her, I don't care.  You know what I'm saying? GRADY watches Vernon give Oola a kiss on the forehead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right. Well, thanks. For the lift.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No sweat. Only do me a favor?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stop calling me Vernon. CRABTREE leans into Grady, WHISPERS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The jacket, Tripp. We need the jacket. GRADY (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, right. Oola. About that jacket...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yea? GRADY looks at the waitress in her pink jersey dress,  snuggled up in the silk wedding jacket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It used to belong to Marilyn Monroe. She had  small shoulders, like you. Most people don't  know that. As Oola smiles, pleased, Vernon shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Man, that book of yours must've been one nutty  motherfucking ride. Vernon points an imaginary gun, fires a friendly cap into Grady, and pulls away. CRABTREE stands stunned.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mind explaining what you just did? GRADY watches the shrinking Galaxie sail under a drooping NORDFEST BANNER, lost in thought.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Came to my senses. CRABTREE Ah. Well. Congratulations. Meanwhile, what is  James supposed to do? Pray for Walter Gaskell  to come to his?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter Gaskell isn't going to send James Leer  to jail, Crabs. I know that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you know he won't expel him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. But I don't think that matters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's very enlightened, Professor. It's  comforting to know that America's children have  you for a teacher. GRADY blinks, ponders this briefly, then looks toward the buildings of the campus, his VOICE still distant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nobody teaches a writer anything. You tell  them what you know. You tell them to find their  voice and stick with it, because that's all you  have in the end. You tell the ones who have it  to keep at it and you tell the ones who don't  to keep at it, too. Because that's the only way  to get where you're going.  (ruefully)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course, it helps if you know where you want  to go.  (thoughtfully)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe that's the only thing--that and Sara-- that's made the last seven years worthwhile. GRADY slides James' knapsack off his shoulder, smiles  cryptically as he considers it. - GRADY (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As for James, he doesn't need me anymore... Without warning, GRADY tosses CRABTREE the knapsack. GRADY (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's got you. CRABTREE stares at the saggy green canvas in his hands,  watches GRADY walk away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Me? What can I do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gee, I don't know, Crabs... (over his shoulder)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Improvise. You're good at that. GRADY continues on, leaving CRABTREE to stand alone, as  he walks toward the buildings in the distance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, Tripp. GRADY stops, turns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You peeked, didn't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I peeked.  GRADY considers this. Nods. It-doesn't seem to matter  anymore

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It really had the makings, Tripp. There was a  lot to admire. I've ...never read anything  quite like it. If there was a Kentucky Derby for editorial bullshit,  Crabtree's last three utterances would finish win, place, and show. And GRADY knows it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not just trying to make me feel better? CRABTREE looks directly at Grady, his old friend.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Scout's honor. CRABTREE and GRADY stare into each other's eyes. Both are acutely aware of the subtext of this conversation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, thanks for that, Crabs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dead quiet. Gradually, STEPS are heard, coming from the  stairwell, then GRADY limps into view.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GRADY surveys the room. Empty chairs. Empty desks. He walks to a WINDOW, the same window he stood at two  afternoons ago when reading James Leer's story. A chill  breeze pitches the fabric of his shirt as he studies the  barren benches and icy walkways of the quad. Finally, he- turns away, settles behind his desk and, reaching into hi pocket, removes the seven remaining pages of his  manuscript. He considers them, then folds them in half  length-wise. He continues, folding the top right corner  down into a triangle along the first crease...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A moment. Then-from the third floor window-a PAPER  AIRPLANE glides into view, soaring then dropping, soaring then dropping, again and again, graceful as a dove.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GRADY hobbles into the lobby just as one of the  auditorium doors swings open. APPLAUSE SWELLS and he spie Sara standing inside, talking to a STUDENT USHER.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sara! Sara turns ...as the door glides shut. As GRADY hustles  forward, Q, wine glass in hand, intercepts him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grady. I have to tell you. I took another look  at Arsonist's Daughter the other night. There's  a description of a bald cypress that left' me  breathless.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pushing past him)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks, Q. I felt the same way about the bank  teller's breasts in your last one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GRADY enters, but Sara is ...gone. He picks his way  behind the back row, scanning the aisles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Professor Tripp. It's Carrie McWhirty, James' tormentor from workshop.  GRADY takes another look around, then drops into the seat next to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you're looking for Hannah, she's on the  aisle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No... But GRADY looks anyway. Hannah sits a dozen rows down the aisle, hair pulled back in a clip, glorious skin gloaming The Goatee Kid sits close beside her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who's that guy she's with? Didn't he used to  be in workshop?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeff. He comes from a long line of tango  dancers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter turns over the last page of-his prepared notes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And now, as those of you who've been with us  in previous years know, we have a tradition of  sorts here at WordFest. I'm speaking, of  course, of The Plums. An anticipatory BUZZ sweeps through the audience as  Walter begins to read from a separate list.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This weekend, Susan Lowery, of North Braddock,  found a publisher for her children's book. The  Loneliest Prawn, Susan, stand up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As a CHUBBY WOMAN stands to acknowledge the applause,  GRADY cranes his neck, searching the sea of seats. To his surprise, he finds CRABTREE sitting prominently in the  front row, in his shirtsleeves, smiling his spookily  complacent smile. James is next to him, now wearing  CRABTREE'S METALLIC SPORTS COAT over Grady's flannel shir

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And Robert Wilkenson--who many of you know for  his City Beat column in the Post-Gazette--has  found a home with Putnam for his new Three  Rivers thriller. Blood Patterns. Robert. A SHORT, BALDING MAN stands briefly then Walter's VOICE  takes a shift in tone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, this next one, I think, is especially  exciting to announce, because it concerns a  student here at the university. Our own James  Leer, a sophomore in English literature, has  found a publisher for his first novel, which I  believe is called The Lovely Parade. GRADY blinks, leans forward, and watches Walter smile  warmly toward the front row. CRABTREE gives James a jab i the ribs and slowly, awkwardly, James rises. Stunned,  Carrie McWhirty turns to the GIRL next to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have a class with him. James hangs-like a scarecrow from a nail, waiting as the  APPLAUSE slows, then sputters, then dies out altogether.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The guy's kind of an alien probe, if you know  what I mean. Grady, in a last attempt to save James from himself, cups Hi his hands around his mouth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take a bow, James! James turns, spots GRADY in the back row, then-a sheepish grin on his face--spreads his arms, hangs his head, and  takes his first sweet public bow. GRADY (cont'd)  (softly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wonder Boy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And finally--and perhaps not least  importantly--Terry Crabtree, of Bartizan, has  also decided to publish my own book--a critical  exploration of the union of Marilyn Monroe and  Joe DiMaggio and its function in American  mythopoetics-which, tentatively, I've entitled  The Last American Marriage.     " Wild, obsequious APPLAUSE. GRADY smiles cynically,  watches Walter take a brief, dignified bow of his own.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Until next year. Thank you, everyone. The LIGHTS come up. As the auditorium empties, CRABTREE  shakes Walter's hand and Jeff and his goatee escort Hanna Green down the aisle, where she drapes her lovely arms  around James. GRADY watches them ail, sitting alone in his row, when  suddenly Sara appears over James' shoulder. She says  something congratulatory, turns, and exits out a side doo GRADY blinks, scrambles up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GRADY bursts into the corridor.'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sara! Its empty. Quiet. GRADY pauses. Somewhere, a HEAVY METAL  DOOR CLOSES. GRADY rushes on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grady, limping badly, turns a corner and sees a DOOR. He  moves to it, pushes past...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...and finds himself standing in a stairwell. He leans  out over the railing, peers down. It's a steep drop, very steep, ending in a small rectangular space, a kind of  basement office, with VENDING MACHINES, PLASTIC CHAIRS, a a COLLAPSIBLE CARD TABLE. GRADY turns back to the door he came through, pushes  against it. Locked. He sighs, looks back at the stairs, h ailing ankle, then sits. He fishes out the Ziploc of-  marijuana, considers the perfectly roiled JOINT floating  atop the bag of buds, but, for once, isn't up to it. The  SOUND of FOOTSTEPS echoes far below and, hopeful they're  Sara's, GRADY pulls himself up, peers over the railing. It's Traxler, with a broom, a big plastic bag.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yo, Traxler.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking up)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Professor Tripp. GRADY considers the Ziploc in his hand, looks down again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you get high, Sam?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Only when I'm working. GRADY hangs-over the railing and lets fly the Ziploc.  It pinwheels through the vortex of stairs, lands at Sam's  feet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Holy shit. Are you serious?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As a heart attack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks-Whoa, Professor Tripp, careful ^here... GRADY is still hanging over the railing-but looking dizzy now. His eyelids flutter and he tips forward-a Steinway o a window ledge-and as he starts to drop... ...there is a SHARP JERK on his- COLLAR, a SHIRT BUTTON  caroms off his cheek, and slowly, he is hauled back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grady, what are you doing, you idiot? GRADY looks up into Sara's freckled face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Looking for you. He wants to say more, he opens his mouth, but then... ALL GOES BLACK AS SARA'S VOICE CALLS... faintly at first, then more forcefully, calling Grady's  name, calling so insistently that the earth seems to RUSH upward until we see that she is... KISSING him or something, and all goes softly... Blue.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GRADY lies in a powder blue paper gown surrounded by blue plastic curtains in a blue room. Through a gap in the  curtains, he can see the bottle of-GLUCOSE that drips  slowly into his arm, and beyond, a window. Flakes of SNOW fall outside. The DOOR SQUEALS, a SHADOW ripples across the blue, then  the curtains part and a RESIDENT with a clipboard appears His NAMETAG says GREENHUT.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I passed out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You did.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've been doing that a lot lately.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So I hear. You've also been smoking a lot of  marijuana, I understand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you think that's why I've been having  these... (grabbing James' term)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... spells?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How long have you been having them?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The last month maybe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How long have you been smoking marijuana?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Spiro T. Agnew was vice president, I believe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's probably not the problem, then. What  about your lifestyle. Any major changes  recently?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've been trying to finish a book...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And your wife left you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that in my chart?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I spoke with the woman who saved your life.  You're lucky she came along when she did. GRADY considers the larger ramifications of this  statement

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (tapping the glucose bottle)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You need to see a doctor, Mr. Tripp. An  internist. And I think you really ought to  consider seeing a therapist, as well.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She told you about. . .

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her dog, yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Actually, it was her husband's dog... Greenhut glances up, looking GRADY in the eyes for the  first time, and GRADY stops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, Mr. Tripp. You have a drug problem, all  right? On top of that, you have a bite on your  ankle that is severely infected. We pumped you  with antibiotics so you'll be fine, but another  day or two and you might have lost the foot. As  for your spells. I'm guessing they're a result  of the anxiety you've been experiencing lately.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're anxiety attacks? That's a little  disappointing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Better luck next time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So is my friend...is Sara still here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. There's no one here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have to see her. As soon as possible. Greenhut studies Grady, calibrating the desperation in  his eyes, then takes a quick glance at his watch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, Mr. Tripp. If you really want to leave,  I can't stop you. But I'm going to write you a  prescription for a course of ampicillin and I  want you to follow it to the end-no matter how  stupid you decide to be with everything else.  All right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GRADY sits in a WHEELCHAIR, watching the snow fail around him as a NURSE escorts him through the tunnel of glass th connects one building to another.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wonder if you could show me something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GRADY stares through the glass. There are only TWO BABIES on display, heads dented from natural delivery, skin purp and crazy with veins.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are these the only ones you have? The nurse's eyes crinkle. GRADY (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kidding...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GRADY pays a TAXI CAB DRIVER, then turns,     looks at  the Gaskell house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GRADY KNOCKS. Nothing. Peers into the living room window. Dark.  He stands helplessly, then spies the greenhouse,  standing ghostly across the yard, feathers of snow drifti onto its roof, melting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GRADY hobbles to the greenhouse, puts both hands to the  glass as he looks inside. Quiet. Empty. Dispirited, he  pulls away, but not before leaving... ...the IMPRINTS of his hands, perfectly etched in the  frost of the glass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The snow continues to fall as GRADY lumbers down the  street. Finally, wearily, he stops, sits his crippled sel on the curb. He plunges his fist into his jacket and.  ..straight through the lining, James Leer's silly little  pistol at the end of his hand. He considers the pistol,  then looks up into the sky. GRADY'S POV - of the SKY...  ...dark and menacing. Suddenly, a THUNDERCLAP shatters  the silence. NEW ANGLE - GRADY ...still sitting with the gun in his  hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as if addressing God)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that a suggestion? GRADY sits, blinking the snow out of his eyes, then TWO  SHAFTS of-LIGHT dance across his shoes. A white Citroen  DS23 appears.  It passes.  Slows.  Stops.  GRADY stares at the car, burbling at the curb, then lifts himself up and makes his way to the driver's window. Sara makes a face, bugging her eyes a little-mad at him, but-  not without humor. Then she rolls down the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm so glad to see you, Sara.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I believe you. Did that nice doctor let you  out? Or-is this you improvising again, Grady?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm through improvising.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Terry told me about Wonder Boys. Is  it true?  Did you lose it all?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I lost it ail.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, Grady. You're such a putz.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you're old. Sara strokes his scalp, takes a gray hair between her  fingers. Yanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ouch. How many?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dozens. It's very sad. Sara smiles at Grady, but the mischief leaves her eyes  when she looks into his, and-she glances away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I went and looked at-some babies just now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (trying to make her laugh)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess you have to go on faith.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (she doesn't)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some times... GRADY studies her as she traces her finger around the  HOSPITAL BRACELET still encircling his wrist.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you tell Walter?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I told Walter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Does he still love you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It didn't come up.  GRADY studies Sara's freckled cheeks, her anxious  profile, then turns her chin gently toward him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well I do. I've always loved you, Sara. I  didn't know it at the time, but I'd always been  waiting for you. My whole life. Because you're  who I need. Because nothing makes sense without  you. Because the best moment of every day is  the moment I first see your face. And because  when you leave a room, there's no reason to be  in it any more. It's just a room again. Sara cocks her head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you just make that up?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shaking his head)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the hospital. I "was kind of excited about  it at-the time, but then I was on pretty heavy  painkillers. She frowns good-naturedly.  GRADY (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Even so...it's still true. Every word. Sara just nods, looks away, her face unreadable. GRADY (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sara, I promise, even though commonsense might  tell you... Sara turns, puts a finger on GRADY's lips...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't write a page when a paragraph will do. GRADY nods, takes her hand. Looks at it as he speaks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't deserve me, you know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know, but sometimes...  Sara turns, looks at Grady. Her eyes are glistening.  SARA (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You just go on faith. GRADY looks into her eyes, then rises, and we do too,  drifting above the streetlights as GRADY limps to the oth side of the car and gets in. As GRADY snaps shut his door the car drifts off, gradually losing itself in- the soft  veil of falling snow. After a moment, GRADY and Sara are  lost too, nothing more than a blur.
